The local Irish parish priest was Reverend Father Tom Curran, who ruled with a rod of iron and regularly preached hour-long fire-and-brimstone Sunday sermons, even in the searing summer heat. Father Curran was a highly educated man who was widely travelled and respected not only by local Catholics but by the Dunedoo community at large. He also liked a Scotch and could give Patrick O'Hagan a run for his money when singing Galway Bay, Danny Boy or I'll Take You Home Again, Kathleen. One of my fondest memories of Father Curran carrying out his priestly duties was the day he visited our class at St Joseph's Convent School, Dunedoo. On this particular day, Father Curran picked up Sister Augustine's `sizzling' cane and managed to break it into pieces. We all thought he should have been instantly canonised and sent straight to heaven.

The Irish influence in Australian politics is also of note. Approximately 40 per cent of members of my party, the Australian Labor Party, are of Irish descent. The initial reason for the strong affinity of the Irish for the Australian Labor Party was the perceived anti-establishment tendency. This attraction was in turn a function of the different social, ethnic and economic backgrounds of those of Protestant English and Catholic Irish backgrounds. Over time, the Irish have more fully assimilated and influenced Australian culture. I believe the greatest contribution of the Irish is their contribution to the sociodynamics of Australian culture, in particular the values for which Australia is famous as a destination for people of all nationalities, religions and creeds. Many of us take for granted the values which we call Australian. For me, the Australian values we hold most dear are the sense of fairness or giving each other a `fair go'. Mateship is also a value for which Australians are world renowned. These values came at a price, from the cultural legacy we owe to the Irish. I will now speak of some of those values.

The first is pluralism. As the historian Patrick O'Farrell points out, it was the determination of the Irish Catholics in Australia not to be put down by the Protestant ascendance in 1915-21 which tipped the balance in Australian society away from exclusivity and homogeneity to a pluralist society. From this we have the tolerant racial and religious values we enjoy today. The second value is tolerance. Racial tolerance has been encouraged by Australian Catholics since early days. We owe our cultural legacy of this view to the religious-cultural dimension of the Irish in Australia. These values have made Australia a respected member of the world community. Tolerance is a value which I hold dear and will protect vigorously.

The third is nationalism. The Irish in Australia saw Australia as their motherland, following the loss of interest in Ireland after the outbreak of civil war in Ireland in 1921. The fourth is the honouring of women in society. The Irish in Australia have played a dominant part in recognising the significant role of women in Australian history. Women such as Mary MacKillop, Anne Summers, Susan Ryan, composer Moya Henderson and Germaine Greer immediately come to mind. Even the Catholic patron saint of Australia is Mary Help of Christians.

The fifth is social justice. As noted, the Irish legacy has seen the active participation of the Irish in secular affairs including the political life of Australia. The Catholic doctrine of `not living by faith alone' has seen active participation in the industrial life of this country as well as other social justice issues. All in all, we are indebted to the Irish for their contribution to making Australia the tolerant, pluralist, democratic society in which we live today. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI am very happy to join with other honourable members in this debate acknowledging the strong and vital contribution made to the values which underpin Australian society by Irish immigrants and their descendants. To see how significant the Irish contribution has been to Australia, we can look at the contemporary population mix in this country and note that one-sixth of Australians can trace their ancestry back to Irish originâwhich is a remarkable amount in a country like Australia.

speech.para: The Irish, of course, have great characteristics. They are very good to be with, their hospitality is magnificent, and those Australian-born people of Irish descent have, I think, improved on the ability of their forefathers to offer warm hospitality and friendship. Just recently I was able to attend a function in my electorate where we were entertained by Irish music and Irish dancing. I must say that there was not one person at that function who did not enjoy the wonderful atmosphere that was generated by the culture and the music of the Irish singers. I did notice that they had advanced their style from what must have been the original Irish style of singing to a bit of rock-and-roll/Irish. That is an interesting mix, and only the Irish could do that.

In my own electorate, many people are proudly of Irish descent, and we also have some very colourful people who claim to be direct descendants of Ned Kelly, the bushranger. The small township of Glenrowan in my electorate, which is near Wangaratta, is the site where Ned Kelly made his famousâor infamousâlast stand.

Just two or three weeks ago I had the pleasure of visiting a group of young unemployed citizens of north-east Victoria who were working in a Work for the Dole project. Their project was to restore some of the old buildings around the old railway station at Glenrowan where some of the famous last stand took place. I would commend to members and their families and friends that, on their way to and from Melbourne, they divert from the Hume Highway into Glenrowan and have a look at the magnificent exhibitions that are there to entertain tourists and to show them some of that history of Australia. Of course, most Irish citizens and pioneers who came to this country did not engage in law lessness, as Ned Kelly did, but it is true that it is part of Australian history and just another colourful example of some of those processes.

The Irish people are very passionate, very friendly and have a wonderful sense of humour. They also have a sense of democracy. It has been a matter of grave concern for all Australians and people in the world to watch what has been happening with the terrorism of the IRA in Ireland, and we can only hope and pray that those problems will be permanently removed from Ireland, from its society and from its democratic government urgently. Unfortunately, I understand that in only the last few days there has been another problem with violence and brutality. I think that is one of the greatest challenges, and I know that Australian born people of Irish descent would share with me the wish that those things be dealt with once and for all and resolved so that the Irish nation, which is making huge progress economically, can achieve its full potential, which I believe has been held back because of the violence, insurrection and brutality existing for so many years in part of Ireland.

But that does not deter us in the spirit of this motion, because we know that many aspects of Australian society are enriched because many Irish people have made Australia their home. We know that some of their forebears did not choose to come here. They were forced to come here as convicts and lived in dreadful circumstances. Only shock and horror can describe the injustices that they suffered back home and their experiences in the early settlement of Australia. But their toughness, their strong moral fibre, their determination and their strong sense of family overcame those problems and they became great citizens of this country. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise in support of the private members motion before the House today. However, before I begin I would like to point out that when I approached most people about speaking on this motion they were taken aback a bit and asked me whether we did not have better things to do with our time. Nevertheless, I am pleased today to add my weight to this motion.

speech.para: Most of the history books and stats tell us that it is impossible to be precise about the extent and character of the Irish element in Australian history. Beyond the obvious, it was considerable and pervasive. Up to a third and no less than a sixth of Australians have Irish heritage. The Irish have made significant contributions, as all the members have stated today, particularly in political lifeâmost notably from this side of the Houseâand in religion, education, business, commerce, sport, music, song and drama.
Like many in this place, I am proud to claim Irish heritage. An article by Gerard Henderson, who seems to write a lot about the Irish, states:

It is not so long ago that many Australians with an Irish background tended to keep their heads down. Before the immigration inflows after World War II, the Irish were the only significant ethnic minority.
A strange thing to think about. The article went on:
In those days, the term Irish was inevitably equated with Catholic. Nowadays, it is somewhat more fashionable to claim some Irish origins.

I am also one of those people proud to claim Irish origins. I am also very proud to recognise my Swiss-Italian roots, which were recently celebrated at the 7th Hepburn Springs Festa. The thing about Catholics is that they tend to marry one another, and you will actually find a lot of Italian-Irish unions. Numerous great-grandparents and one very special grandmother were born in Ireland. I generally categorise myself as a Melbourne Mick, born of stock which still sticks with its ties to the roots of the Irish potato famine. A Melbourne Mick is not just a Catholic but one born and raised in the ethos of all that is Irish.

My grandmother, I think, typifies all that is Irish in Australia. She was born in Ballsbridge in Dublin, Mary Walsh. She went to work in England during World War I and there met my grandfather who was serving with the Australian Army in England after World War I in the postwar clean-up. They sailed to Australia. She was in only her early 20s and then spent the rest of her 93 years here. She had 10 children. They produced at least 36 grandchildren that I could add up before I came down today and I have no recollection of how many great-grandchildren she has up to now. She died at the age of 93, but she never lost that accent. She was always Irish, but Australia was the greatest place on earth to live. She would never have wanted to live anywhere else. In those 73 years in Australia she actually went home only twice: once in 1961 when there was an enormous cold spell, and she turned around and came home and said that Ireland was too damn cold and she was never going back there again as long as she lived.

Like many migrants to this place, her life was not easy in this country. In the Second World War, my grandfather joined up, leaving her to run a small shop and look after her 10 children. She never complained, she never whinged and she never looked for sympathy or handouts in all those years. She knew everything that was happening around her. She was adamant about listening to the radio and keeping up. And there was always room for one more or 20 more. I can remember eating in rotations at my grandmother's place. She would cook a roast and it would go on and on forever. She would feed the men first, then the pregnant women, then the older boys and eventually she would get down to the women and children. After about three hours, you would finally get a plate of roast lamb and vegetables in front of youâlots of potatoes and lots of good, strong cups of tea.

But she was always there, she was always giving, and I think that typifies the Irish-Australian spirit that we are here to commend today. She did not have a sentimental bone in her body, though, and she would never accept or give presents. Any presents that were given to her were always given away, particularly flowersâthey were always straight down to the church. Flowers were not for home; they were for other people. I think that is another thing about the Irish: there is always someone less fortunate than themselves. She had a deep and undying faith in her religion, and she was very pleased to give one back to Godâmy uncle became a priest. She typified the Irish. She was none too fond of the Queen, and that has been passed down to all the generations after her. This stoic approach to life, coupled with this sense of social justice, paints for me the picture of Irish life in Australia.

The other small thing that I would have liked to have spoken about was the Irish famine, particularly the 4,000 orphan girls who came to Australia during the years 1848 to 1850. In December 1998, a memorial was erected in Williamstown to commemorate this group. It was 150 years after the date of the first arrival in Hobsons Bay. It was in memory of one million people who had died in Ireland during the great hunger of 1845 to 1852. It read:
In praise of the courage of tens of thousands of dispossessed Irish who sailed to Hobsons Bay to build a new life.

They did build a new life. Author Thomas Keneally wrote about the British sponsoring the Irish orphans. The Irish have in many respects framed the character of Australia, and I commend to the House the motion before us today. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âBetween 16 per cent and 30 per cent of Australians lay some claim to being of Irish descent, depending on whose source you want to use. I have links on both my father's and my mother's sides. A cursory glance at the list of members and senators in this place reveals at first blush that at least 55, or around 25 per cent, have surnames which could be of Irish origin. If you took female lineage and some more obscure surnames into account, there would be many more.

speech.para: Many Australians seem to enjoy the genealogical pursuit of tracing their Irish ancestors. Some put that down to romanticism, but I suspect it has something to do with the overwhelming legacy of Irish values that permeate the Australian psyche. These values have flowed on in a homogeneous society and have spread outside genetic lines. Hence our nation holds Ireland as one of its parent countries. This is not the time for a history lesson, but it is well known that Irish convicts were transported here, first to New South Wales, in the period 1791 to 1820. Some were Irish state prisoners, others were convicts tried in Ireland and still others were of Irish extraction tried outside Ireland.

Notable amongst these were the rebel remnants of the 1798 and 1803 Irish rebellions, transported to New South Wales during the period 1797-1806. As my colleague the member for Chisholm mentioned, a lot of women came out here in the 18th century, and they made a significant contribution to Australian life. The women were not convicts of that period, but the convicts who did come here on average were 19 years of age, so they gave most of their adult lives to this land.

In my first speech in this place, I paid tribute to the Sisters of Mercy and to the Christian Brothers, who taught me in my early days and who cultivated my love of history, literature and debate. They had very strong links to Ireland. Perhaps the most enduring characteristic the Irish have given their Australian descendants is that of a sense of humour and a healthy disrespect for authoritarianism.

I remember my great friend John Ahernâfather of Michael Ahern, a former Premier of Queenslandâtelling the story of the funeral he went to at Esk. This is one of the greatest Irishisms that I have ever heard. It had been raining the day before the funeral, and the grave had half filled with water. When the cortege finally got to the cemetery, they lowered the coffin into the grave but it floated. They tried to weigh it down with dirt, but it kept popping up through the sludge. Eventually someone had the good presence of mind to take the grieving widow away, and another fellow went to his buckboard and came back with a brace and bit and put holes around the coffin. Eventually they buried this poor man at sea. They finally filled the grave in and, as they all stood there looking down on this terrible mess, someone looked to the local Irish sage for some words of wit and wisdom. The sage looked down and said, `If I live to the day I die, and I bloody well hope I don't, I will never be buried in Esk to be drowned every day of me life.'

This great sense of humour is one of the contributions of the Irish. They have also made contributions to the church, to the legal profession, to the police, to medicine, to railways and substantially to agriculture. In every area where there has been a cutting edge contribution to be made, there has inevitably been found an Irish linkage. It is an interesting dichotomy that, despite the fact that the Irish had great troubles with England in their own countryâand those of Irish heritage have always had a healthy interest in and concern for these issues, as the member for Chisholm pointed outâit has never impinged on their loyalty to Australia or, for that matter, to its part in the British Commonwealth. Some would find this an inconsistency or contradiction, but I see it as the hallmark of great tolerance and loyalty to an adopted land.

It is interesting to note that the first Anglo-Saxon prelate of the Roman Catholic Church to be knighted since the Reformation was an Irish-Australian Catholic, Sir James Duhig. Irishmen and those of Irish heritage have emerged at crucial times in Australian history. Another strange contradiction was that of an Irishman, Redmond Barry, judging another Irishman, Ned Kelly. Peter Lalor was an Irish rebel who led our first uprising and went on to become Speaker of the Victorian parliament. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âAustralia is undoubtedly the most Irish country in the world other than Ireland itself. As other speakers have indicated, up to one-third of all Australiansâand I would suggest it is possibly higher than thatâclaim at least some Irish ancestry. I might add that I include myself, along with other speakers. From the First Fleet, through the terrible events surrounding the great famine and up until today, Irish men and women have made a great contribution to this country.

speech.para: Of course a great many of them, particularly in earlier days, did not leave Ireland in circumstances that were terribly good, from any point of view. In the excellent book, The Great Shame, by Thomas Keneally, which was published at the end of last year, a number of incidents are told. One that particularly took my attention was a quote from a well-known 19th century Irishman, Thomas Francis Meagher. He said:

One scene I witnessed in the morning of my boyhood . . . left upon my memory an impression that can never be effaced. That scene was the departure of an immigrant-ship from the quay of my native city of Waterford . . . On the deck of the ship were huddled hundreds of men, women and children.

Young as I was, I had heard enough of the cruelty that had, for years and years, been done to Ireland, to know that her people were leaving her not from choice but from compulsion; that it was not the sterility of the soil, or any other unfavourable dispensation of nature, but the malignant hostility of laws and practices.

From early settlement, the Irish influence has been fundamental to understanding Australia. Another great Australian author, historian Russell Ward, in his book The Australian Legend , which is a history of the development of Australian national identity, had the following to say about the convict era:
The chief gains of the convict era were ideas of one man being as good as another, of the mateship of the chain gang, of rejection of authoritarian values, of acceptance of democracy.

The Irish were at the forefront here, retaining their own values in protest against the values of their masters. These deeply entrenched Australian values are reflected through many, if not most, of the great legends of Australian society, be it Eureka, Burke's inland expedition, the Kelly episodes, the conscription debates of the First World War or the development of the labour movement in Australia with the trade unions and the ALP.

Australian nationalism is closely linked to the Irish tradition. Certainly Australian republicanism is inextricably linked to the Irish tradition. The Australian tradition of pluralism and tolerance draws heavily on the Irish. In colonial Australia and into this century, as other speakers have indicated, the Irish were the largest non-British part of then multicultural Australia. They recognised the importance of pluralism and tolerance and of cultural and social difference as a basis for their own role in Australia's development.

The Irish influence has been absolutely fundamental to modern Australia's acceptance of social diversity and of the importance of social justice based on fairness and equity. All of this has been vital in shaping a democratic and pluralist Australia, which has so successfully been enhanced by further waves of immigration from all over the world, particularly in the postwar period. Without the Irish tradition and the Irish maintenance of the importance of tolerance, pluralism and a sense of justice, I do not believe that Australia would have been as successful as it has in its post-Second World War immigration programs.

The Irish have been great contributors to Australian society's best features. I believe that openness, a very high degree of enjoyment of life's simple pleasures, the provision of hospitality and the acceptance of all in our society based on equality are values that Australia inherits from our Irish tradition.

talk.start.para: âOrder! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

âLast week in this chamber when speaking on the budget, I talked about international poverty and social injustice. I said that the matter has two dimensions. One is the international dimension and the other is the way in which poverty and social injustice are increasingly issues in our society.

speech.para: It is pretty sad that so much of our contemporary political debate is focused very narrowly on economic indicators and not sufficiently on more social and human questions, including those about poverty and social injustice. Indeed, the words `social justice', which were prominent in the policy debates of the late 1980s and the early 1990s, appear to have disappeared from the public debate. Certainly they do not engender much interest in the media nowadays.

Much of public policy and public debate has shifted away from what might be called a broad focus on the human consequences of human policy decisions to a much more narrow focus on economic indicators. That is not to say that economics or economic indica tors are not important; it says that we need to focus more on some of these social dimensions. It is time that we reintroduced the concept of social justice, especially in Australia, into our public policy discussions.

Several years ago, in my book Understanding social justice: an Australian perspective, I attempted to sum up the issues concerned with defining social justice and what was important in trying to develop a socially just society. I understand that some people now feel it has become totally unfashionable to talk about social justice. One reason is that they feel within the context of a globalised economy the international pressures on the Australian economy are such that the capacity of the government to deliver social justice and programs concerned with the eradication of poverty has been significantly reduced.

While it is true that the role of the state in different societies has been reduced to a certain degree as a result of economic globalisation, I do not think we should use this as an excuse to run away from our responsibility as legislators and policy makers to protect the most disadvantaged and needy in our community. If we get to the point where we use economic globalisation as a reason for not putting into place policies designed to protect the weakest and poorest members of our communityâthose who are suffering the mostâwe lose our whole rationale as a civilisation and a society.

It is in this context that I want to address a couple of questions about what has been happening in Australia. Unfortunately, in the last few years, especially during the coalition government, we have had an increase in poverty and social inequality in this country. This increasing poverty and social inequality is reflected in the fact that the richest 200 people in Australia have increased their wealth by 20 per cent, according to the BRW review of a couple of weeks ago. However, those in the bottom ranks have actually reduced their incomes and, in particular, their access to important services such as education and health. I refer especially to certain areas of health not covered by Medicare, such as dental care. They have also reduced their access to welfare in emergencies.

In the early 1980s in my own electorate of Calwell, the situation was one of significant poverty and inequality. As a result of programs put into place between 1983 and 1996, especially up to the early 1990s, we had a significant improvement in this situation. For example, school retention rates for children in the area of Broadmeadows increased dramatically, especially in the first nine years or so of the Labor government. We had a very positive situation in which, for example, we went from about 30 per cent of children who began high school finishing high school to something like 80 per centâin fact, higher than 80 per centâby the early 1990s. I regret to say that now the situation is going backwards. We now have a bigger drop-out rate in high schools from the young people in my electorate, especially that part of my electorate. And that is not unique to my electorate but is the case in many electorates where there are significantly economically disadvantaged people living and trying to make a life for themselves.

That means the welfare agencies in our area are coming under increasing pressure. For example, the Uniting Church in my area, which provides food for the most disadvantaged people, people who in distressed situations come and seek assistance when finding themselves in emergency circumstances, is now unable to cope with the demand.

Homelessness is also a very big issue. With the reduction in investment in public sector housing by both state and federal governments, we have a situation in Australia where the queues of poor people applying for housing have increased dramatically. That a society as wealthy as Australia should have so many homeless peopleâthousand and thousands of homeless peopleâin the queues, with only the most dramatic cases being able to gain access to Housing Commission accommodation,

This is very serious. It is a matter that needs to be addressed. It is not a question that needs to be avoided. It is fair enough for the Treasurer to talk in glowing terms about a growing economy. But who is the economy growing for? Which sector is growing? What is happening to the homeless in our communi ty, to the poorer section in our community, to the long-term unemployed in our community?

Every day we have the Minister for Employment Services telling us how wonderful some of his programs are. I can tell you that in my electorate people cannot even get on to those programs because of the cuts that have been made to the provision of services in this area of training; even in the area of Work for the Dole, people cannot even get on to the programs. There has been a reduction in Centrelink in my electorate. We have had several managers leave because of the enormous pressure being generated by so many people being in trouble in my electorate in that area of Melbourneâindeed, I believe this is also the case in similar areas in Sydney and other parts of Australia where we have real levels of poverty.

As I said at the beginning, the responsibility to provide for the most disadvantaged in our community should rest with the government. The fundamental principles of social justice as outlined by philosophers such as John Rawls and others still stand. Notwithstanding the fact of globalisation, we in this community are still able to use resources to help that sector of the community. We have a responsibility as a society for that poor sector. We have a responsibility for these people. We should stop passing the buck between the state and federal governments and we should stop saying, `Well, in general the economy is growing; therefore, people in distressed situations don't need our help.' Those peopleâthe long-term unemployed, the homeless, the unemployed youth and many others who are in distressed situationsâdo need our help. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âAnother area in which poverty is a problem is rural Australia. We need to do an awful lot to improve the fate of people in rural areas, and rural industries really do need some very close attention from governments. I rise today to discuss the fate and future of the University of Queensland, Gatton campus. This is a facility best known to members, and to Australians, in general as the Queensland Agricultural College. Traditionally, it has been known by that title for 102 years. The Queensland Agricultural College, as it was known, was amalgamated with the University of Queensland in 1990. In 1991 the Bulletin magazine ranked the Gatton campus of the University of Queensland, as it had become, as `the top tertiary institution for agricultural education in eastern Australia'. That is quite an achievement.

speech.para: In 1997 the university's Faculty of Natural Resources, Agriculture and Veterinary Sciences resolved to move all its activities to the Gatton campus. Some of its existing activities are spread all over the place, and I will mention those a little later. The idea was to establish the kind of world-class facilities that were obviously conjured up in people's minds when the idea of amalgamation with the University of Queensland was first mooted. Those world-class facilities, as outlined in 1997, should be worth something in the region of $22 million. It was only decided to proceed down that path after undertaking a total of seven reviews of the Faculty of Natural Resources, Agriculture and Veterinary Sciences.

Just to run through some of the dimensions of that faculty, it consists of three schools with a staff of 410 and 2,346 full- and part-time students. Teaching and research programs are conducted presently at St Lucia and Gatton with field stations at Pinjarra Hills, an outer suburb of Brisbane, Redland Bay, another area very close to the centre of Brisbane, and Mt Cotton. In addition, there are veterinary clinics at four locations and St Lucia. Research is carried out at Longpocket and at CSIRO facilities at Cannon Hill and Toowoomba.

To meet the plan to amalgamate all these disparate interests on one site at Gatton, $5 million a year was to have been spent at Gatton from 1991 onwards. Unfortunately, though, in that time the business school at the University of Queensland Gatton campus was transferred out. Instead of the growth that was promised, nothing has been transferred in to replace it. Over that timeâthat is, 1998-99âa total of 800 students were lost, 20 teaching and support staff were lost and a further transfer of lower OP courses to the TAFE system is mooted, reducing the total number of students to 2,150 next year. That will be down from 3,346 in 1996.

The college is a very important facility locally. It provides 1,900 jobs equivalents and generates a turnover of $22 million. It is the biggest single industry in the Lockyer Valley. The Vice-Chancellor of the University of Queensland, Professor Hay, has continually maintained since the college was restructured in 1996 that the veterinary science facility would be located in Gatton to offset the loss of those students which I spoke about earlier.

There are three shires that are principally affected by the concerns over Gatton Collegeâthat is, the Laidley, Esk and Gatton shires. They are naturally working together to highlight the promises that have been made by the university in the time since it took control of the Gatton campus. They have written letters to the governing body of the university's Gatton campus, which included this statement:
It is crystal clear to us that, without a serious build up of numbers, the Gatton campus will reach critically low numbers and its closure is inevitable.

That is obviously a high level of concern. That concern is certainly shared by the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government in the coalition federal government. He has written to the Vice-Chancellor summing it up very well. He said:

. . . to allow Gatton to wither on the vine will bring the University of Queensland into disrepute in regional Queensland and beyond. Such a reversal would be in the face of an emerging bi-partisan commitment in Australia to regional development. It would be inconsistent with our Government's commitment to rural and regional Australia.

In that same letter he also reminded the Vice-Chancellor that securing a future for regionally based universities was an intent of the unified national system of higher education. I think that remains a very important goal that we need to keep in mind.

I believe that the state and federal governments should take a greater interest in the issue and in the future of this higher learning institution which primarily deals with agriculture and the important resourcing of our growing rural industries. I say `growing' in an optimistic sense because, for some time now, far too many of those industries have been reliant on government assistance just to keep things ticking over until drought breaks and they can get back on their feet and that sort of thing. I believe that the state government should be paying particular attention because that is who owns the assets.

When the former coalition state government was in power, they proposed the establishment of an animal health institute located under one roof at the Gatton campus. That was the announcement made by Minister Trevor Perrett. He suggested that we get the resources of the Department of Primary Industries, TAFE, Gatton and also the CSIRO under one roof at Gatton. Now that we have a new state government, that has apparently fallen through. They seem to have backed away. Instead, they are now talking about what they call a multi-locational campus at Gatton, St Lucia and Toowoomba. They are referring to the CSIRO as having possibly only part-time involvement. I do not know what that means, but it sounds very wishy-washy. If we want to have a multi-locational campus, I think we have probably got it already, because the DPI, St Lucia and all these places are very far apart. They are certainly multi-locational as they are.

All of this brings back to my mind the initial intention, which was to establish this wonderful world-class facility. We have to get that back on the agenda. From reports I have had back, I believe that the Vice-Chancellor, Professor Hay, is keen on that. We must continue to support him in that endeavour and get the message out to the University of Queensland Senate. Why is this important? It is important not just because of the negative impact that all of this has on the whole region, which I obviously represent, but also because of the impact on rural industries in Australia and because of the fact that those industries are facing an incredible revolution as the impact of biotechnology, in particular, begins to be felt.
I quote now from a paper called Biotechnology in Australia by Dr Peter French under the auspices of the Federation of Australian Scientific and Technological Societies. The paper states:

It is clear from this brief overview that many of Australia's competitor countries are positioning their biological industries to take advantage of the biotechnology revolution. There is clearly not the same level of activity taking place in Australia currently. This should be cause for some serious concern and subsequent remedial action by government.

Biotechnology is about to have a big impact on Australia. I have heard people say that it is going to have a bigger impact than did the silicon chip. In particular, it will impact on agricultural industries. I now refer to another article which quoted Trevor Flugge from the Australian Wheat Board. Referring to investing in biotechnology and in biotechnological research, he said:
If we don't do that, in the long termâfive, 10, 15 yearsâwe will be at the mercy of multinationals as to what technology is available and, secondly, as to what you pay for it.

That is obviously a concern. The University of Queensland has established its own Institute for Molecular Biology. This project has attracted $200 million in a very short space of time, but I think it is important to bear in mind that while we set out for the cure for cancer we must also look at the issues in relation to yield, in relation to the benefits that can come from genetic engineering and from biotechnology in the development of better crops, in the development of better ways to carry out farming and in the development of better food for people to consume. That I think is a very important issue, something that the Gatton college, under the University of Queensland, could certainly be a leading institute in following and something we should all be looking to invest a great deal of time and effort in. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âAs we all know, this is the International Year of Older Persons, a time when we should be celebrating the contribution that older people have made to our country, a time when we should be looking at what their needs are and a time when we recognise their role in our society. To date, the major initiative of the Howard government for older Australians is to introduce a new tax, a tax that will attack the standard of living of older Australians and impact on every aspect of their lives.

speech.para: The Australian Bureau of Statistics household expenditure data has shown that 75 per cent of pensioners' total weekly budget will be affected by the GST. It will be hit by the Howard-Costello-Democrat GST. I really do not think that is the sort of thing we should be doing in this the Year of Older Persons. St Vincent de Paul declared last Friday that the modified GST, the Howard-Costello-Democrat GST, was `unfair' and `un-Australian' and would hit those older people in our communityâthe people we should be celebrating, and the people whose contributions we should be recognising.

The compensation offered in the GST package is totally inadequate. Australian seniors will have to pay a GST on transport costs. Australian seniors will have to pay a GST on their electricity and on their telephone. The food debacle that the Costello-Howard GST is going to deliver to Australian seniors will only discriminate against them. They will not be able to buy a book without having a GST placed on it. This government is waging a war on older Australians. That is this government's contribution to older Australiansâto wage a war on them.

After question time today, I raised the issue that the Minister for Aged Care had not answered a question I placed on the Notice Paper on 7 December last year. This really shows the commitment of that minister to the seniors in Australia and in particular in my electorate. One part of that question asked:

Is it a fact that proportionally the aged population of the electoral division of Shortland is among the highest in Australia but that its per capita nursing home/hostel bed rate is half the national average; if so, why?

The minister has not seen fit to answer my question to date. I certainly hope she takes time out of her `busy day' to answer that question, to be accountable to the seniors who live in the electorate of Shortland and to the seniors who live within Australia, because throughout the country the nursing home/ hostel rate is inadequate.

I am not satisfied with the GST being the only legacy that this Year of Older Persons will deliver to the seniors in Shortland. It is because of that that I decided I would make sure that the voice of the seniors in Shortland was heard. Michael Whiteside, a social work student at Newcastle University, has undertaken a project in Shortland. He has been working out of my office. He has had a placement in my electorate office. I would like to put on record my thanks to Michael for the fine work he has done. Michael is looking at the needs and concerns of the seniors who live in the Shortland electorate. I believe seniors have played such an important role in our society that we need to work out a long-term strategy to meet their needs.

At the conclusion of this project, which Michael is so ably handling, we will develop a three to five-year plan aimed at improving the quality of life and making aspects of life more accessible to the senior people in the Shortland electorate. As part of this project Michael set up a steering committee. Once again, he has shown a lot of initiative in getting out into the community, listening to people and selecting the right people to be able to serve and guide the services for older people in the Shortland electorate. The steering committee consists of a representative from Home and Community Care; a former aged care assessment team worker, who is presently working with the community dementia unit; a representative from the Hunter Network, a central body for the various carer support groups in the area; a representative from Lake Macquarie City Council; a third-year social work student, who is Michael; and three concerned constituents from the Shortland electorate. We have also had input from the Wyong Shire Council.

The chair of this committee is a woman, Laraine Dunn, who has had a long association with the fitness of the older community. She was instrumental in the Heart Moves program, which is a program designed at promoting fitness for seniors. Michael went along to one of the aerobics programs that Laraine runs. When he returned to the office he was very red in the face and he showed that the programs that these older Australians undertake and the fitness of these older Australians is at quite a high level.

The purpose of this committee is to set goals and develop strategies to address the needs of seniors that Michael has identified in his project. Some of the information that we have received to date is that transport is a major issue within the electorate, particularly in the southern part where transport is run by a private bus company. This only goes to demonstrate the effect that the private sector running a monopoly service has on the senior population. If the legislation for the full sale of Telstra goes through, this will also disadvantage older people. They will have to pay more for that vital telephone service as it is imperative that older Australians have access to telephones.

Along with the transport services in the southern part of the Shortland electorate, which is located on the Central Coast of New South Wales, poor timetabling and the vastness of the area also contribute to the problems of transport. There are also issues both within Wyong Shire Council and Lake Macquarie City Council that the local government needs to address, including the footpaths, guttering and other issues. It is a whole of government approach, and I think all areas of government need to look at the needs of our seniors.

The community transport scheme offers an alternative to older Australians. It operates under the HACC programâa program which has been slashed by this government and which has been under pressure because there is a high demand for the service, the service is not growing and the service providers have had to prioritise their clients. That means that the seniors within Shortland are being denied access to the transport that they need. Those people living in the isolated areas are the ones who are most at risk. I am sure that many members on the other side of this House would like to see an extension of this scheme rather than a contraction. One of the outstanding groups within the community I represent is the Swansea Neighbour Aid Incorporated transport group which provides a vital shopping and transport service to the people of the area.

The lack of resources and coordination of services within the area is a major problem, and it appears that the vast amount of money that this government is saving by pushing the policy of keeping seniors in their homes is not being put into services. It is imperative that, if people are to stay out of nursing homes and hostels, the services are there for them; it should not just be a cost cutting exercise. There is a critical shortage of hostel and nursing home beds within the Shortland electorate and this forces people into the public hospital system. This in itself creates a problem for the hospital system and for other people in the community who seek to gain admission to those hospitals.

I would like to conclude by condemning the Howard government for its betrayal of the older people in our community. There are many older people who are very fit and active and still making enormous contributions to our community. Many of the voluntary organisations in our community would not be able to function without the input from older Australians. I would like to thank all those people in the Shortland electorate who have given many hours of their service freely. I make a commitment to them that, by the end of the Year of Older Persons, we will deliver the services they need and listen to their voices. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThere are some in the oppositionâand unfortunately we have just heard one; and it is purely coincidental that I should follow her and wish to speak on a number of the same issuesâand there are certainly some in the wider community who like to put economic issues and policies in one box and then drum up arguments that social justice and social equity issues belong in another box. In truth, fairness, equity and social justice rely on sound economic policy and management. Our tax system must be adequate to meet Australia's social needs. It must not leave debt from our generation to our children's generation and it must provide for an ageing population. Labor and, I stress, some spokes persons in the charitable sector are unwilling to face up to these realities.

speech.para: It has taken the election of a Liberal government at the national level and also in my home state of South Australia to demonstrate how families, pensioners and the less well-off benefit when government debt is reduced and balance is restored to the nation's finances. As I have said in this place before, South Australia has suffered from Labor's double whammy. Prior to the 1996 federal election, the former government ran up Commonwealth debt by almost $80 billion in its last five years of office. The consequences of this fiscal mismanagement are manifest and far-reaching. Since 1996 the coalition has repaid more than a quarter of that debt and has set aside a further $9 billion just to meet the cost of the government's interest bill. That $9 billion could have been injected into our schools, public hospitals and services for the frail and the aged. Labor's legacy in South Australia has been even worse; it has been debilitating. Before it lost office in 1993, the former state government racked up more than $8 billion in debt. Given the population of South Australia, that has been a tragedy.

The Howard-Costello team has worked hard over the past three years to meet its goal of no Commonwealth debt. But this is not debt reduction for the sake of debt reduction. If Australian families are to continue to benefit from the low home interest rates, we must persevere with sound economic management. Similarly, if small business is to be encouraged to borrow, to invest and to create employment opportunities, it is vital that the government continues with this sound economic management. It is high time that the opposition and those representing the charitable organisations started to accurately represent the facts about the positive impact that this debt reduction strategy and the proposed new tax package will have on families, pensioners and those with special needs.

In her dissenting report to the committee looking into the new tax system, my colleague Senator Sue Knowles made clear her concerns that many of the witnesses appearing before the Senate committee had founded their submissions on information that was factually flawed. I can understand my colleague's frustration. During the campaign, I met with a representative from one charitable organisation. He told me at the time that no other candidate had had the time to meet with him but asked me to believe his version of the government's tax package while confessing that he actually had not examined the policy at all. He also argued that as a member of the government I would have no understanding of poverty. Sadly, he had no appreciation of the understanding I have of those in my electorate or for any personal experience I might have had during my working life prior to entering parliament.

On a more recent occasion, I met with representatives of several charitable organisations which have in the past thanked me for my assistance in seeking financial support and for my promotion of them in my community newsletter. Most unfortunately, these individuals commenced by saying that they had come to see me because of the size of my margin. I remind the House that, if the size of my margin was all that preoccupied my mind, I would never have attempted to enter parliament in the first place, nor would I have worked on some of the issues that I have over the past six years.

My aim has always been to do my best for my electorate and to do what is right for our country to make it a better place. Incredibly, these representatives did not know that this government had already legislated to ensure that the elderly citizens, those they claim to represent, now receive a pension payment of 25 per cent of male average weekly earnings, nor were they aware that the four per cent increase in pensions, including the 1.5 per cent real increase announced in the tax package, will over the period of the forward estimates ensure that the single pension rate stay appreciably above the 25 per cent of male average weekly earnings.

Despite the availability of the Vos report, the tax reform legislation and the accompanying explanatory material since December last year, it is my experience that some charitable sector representatives are not properly briefed about the effect of the GST on those they claim to represent. It is a matter of fact that no GST will be paid by registered charities on purchases or non-commercial services. Similarly, it is clear to anyone who cares to look at the legislation that the fringe benefits tax cap of $17,000 of grossed up taxable value per employee is fair and allows a charitable organisation to maintain an employment cost advantage while removing the scope for abuse.

I would like to make it clear that I admire much of the work done by the charitable sector in our community, but some individuals do themselves no favours in the wider community by inaccurately addressing the facts and by sometimes sounding like spokespersons for the ALP. Where were these people when Labor was in government and running up debt, debt owned by every Australian? I was grateful that Archbishop Faulkner invited me to address the Council of Catholic Priests on the subject of tax reform during the election campaign. Archbishop Faulkner demonstrated his preference for a balanced and informed debate on that matter, and I congratulate him for it.

I wish now to draw the House's attention to the recent vote in the South Australian parliament on the leasing of ETSA. As the editorial in yesterday's Sunday Mail noted, the parliament's decision to proceed with the lease means that:

We now have a fresh start for South Australiaâa new mindset is in place to send us forward with renewed confidence. . . . This state of ours has a new lease of life. As Premier John Olsen aptly put it, we will be able to go into the next century with financial freedom for our kids.

My state colleagues are deserving of the most sincere congratulations for their efforts to lease ETSA and to reduce Labor's State Bank debt. But it would be remiss of me not to acknowledge the crucial role played by two Labor MLCsâone could describe them as old Labor rather than new Labor. They played a crucial part in this debate. Trevor Crothers joined Terry Cameron to vote with the government. Like Norm Foster, a former member of the Legislative Council, they have shown themselves to be above party politics when it comes to the interests of the people of South Australia. They put the jobs of young South Australians ahead of their own.

When faced with the choice of voting with the ALP, which had failed to produce an economically viable alternative to the leasing of ETSA, or to support the government, Mr Crothers very sensibly chose the latter. When pressed as to why he had voted against his party, the member simply stated that his vote was forced by necessity.

It was with a similar sense of purpose that former MLC Norm Foster opted to cross the floor and vote with the Liberal state government in the early 1980s to ensure that the Roxby Downs mine proceeded. As a result, South Australia is home to the nation's largest private sector infrastructure project. Were it not for the courage of that sole Labor member to break ranks and support what he knew to be a winner for South Australia, we would not have the benefit now of a $3.5 billion project or the 1,500-plus jobs that it has generated.

There are some lessons through all of this. In the lead-up to the sale of Australia National, two union leaders at the time, John Crossing and Rex Phillips, who represented the Public Transport Union, were prepared to work with me and to work with the government. Rex Phillips later lost his job, such is the way Labor pays back those who cross them. One would have to ask the question: will any Labor senator cross the floor and stand up for their own state? Will any Labor senator do what is right for their state and their country when it comes to a tough decision? I think not, but I would hope that that may be the case.

There are times when one needs to take a bipartisan approach in this job, as the foreign minister has done today in announcing that we will support the member for Holt as he seeks to take up the position at UNESCO. I will be campaigning for him as the government's representative to UNESCO. That is perhaps an example of how the people of this country would expect us to take a more bipartisan approach, particularly when economic management is so important to this country. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI want to raise a couple of matters during the grievance debate this afternoon. All of my fellow Australians are horrified at the serious allegations that have been made that a Chinese woman, Mrs Zhu Quing Ping, was deported from Australia whilst 8Â½ months pregnant and returned to mainland China. This was first raised by Senator Harradine and Amnesty International. China's one-child policy meant that the baby was going to be aborted, and indeed was.

speech.para: We are all reassured, following the calls for an independent inquiry, that Minister Ruddock has appointed Tony Ayers to conduct such an inquiry. I want to assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the House that I have the absolute highest regard for Tony Ayers, a public servant who retired as Secretary to the Department of Defence but had loyally and diligently served the governments of the day of whatever particular flavour.

I think the debate now has deepened with what has been revealed at Senate estimates by Senator Quirke, and that is that there has been an allegation that not only was this woman forcibly deported but drugs were administered prior to her boarding the plane. Indeed, on 60 Minutes last night there was a further allegation that she had pleaded with Australian Immigration officials to have the pregnancyâan 8Â½ month pregnancyâinduced. Inducing pregnancies is not such a radical procedure. It is frequently done. In fact, doctors are known to induce babies, particularly around Christmas time, to facilitate their own holidays. But this now, I think, raises a whole series of questions that need to be answered. I need to say to my fellow Australians thatânotwithstanding these additional allegations of drugging, the additional allegations of pleading to have the baby inducedâboth Minister Ruddock and the Prime Minister have rejected the calls by Con Sciacca, the shadow minister, to have a judicial inquiry.

I think we need to set the parameters of the difficulties Tony Ayers will face as the person conducting the inquiry and why there should be a judicial inquiry. Firstly, Mr Ayers has to, I think, in his report satisfy everyone that he is able to account for every Australian official who was present at the time of deportation. One wonders, given that this is an internal inquiry of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, how he will be able to ascertain whether other people, either from law enforcement or other departments or other statutory organisations, were present. But that is what he will have to do to be able to provide an accurate accounting of everyone who was present.

Given the serious allegation of drugging, will Mr Ayers have the capacityâas a judicial inquiry wouldâto do two things: firstly, compel witnesses to answer truthfully about what they know and, more importantly, offer those who volunteer information some protection that they will be not victimised by their respective departments or organisations? The Australian Federal Police in transporting a prisoner, say, from Canberra to Perth do not have the legal authority to drug such a person, nor should they. Mr Ayers has to say under what authority the department, as it appears, routinely drugs people when they are deported.

I have to say that, as a member of parliament, I am delighted to assist many people to come to Australia who are related to people in my electorate. But it is also true that some overstay their visas and are properly deported. I am horrified that they may be drugged. I think it is outrageous. The shadow Attorney-General is here in the House, and I am sure he would say that there is no legislation that would cover drugging people in these circumstances, as it would be an invasion on the person. It would be torturous. If this is a practice, what is the head of power that is being used, and what are the protocols being established? What are the guidelines? I think Mr Ayers has to lay that out in his inquiry.

Can I ask whether Mr Ayers will be travelling to China to interview this woman to get her side of the story. Will the Attorney-General be providing legal aid for her not only to respond to any questions put to her by Mr Ayers but, more particularly, to exercise any legal rights she may have had to resist this? Does Australian law protect women who are 8Â½ months pregnant from returning to a country where we know that pregnancy will be aborted? I cannot tell you the law, but I would like to think that if the matter got to the High Court they would have a strong view that this was illegal, that this would not be allowed to happen in an Australian democracy.

I noticed that the shadow minister today has renewed his call for a judicial inquiry. I think every member of parliamentâit does not matter whether you are on the opposition side or on the government sideâwould feel, under these circumstances that have given Australia such a bad name, that I think have left every member of parliament with a bad taste in their mouth, that there should be a completely open and full judicial investigation that can compel witnesses to answer, compel departmental officers to tell the truth and that can provide protection for any witness.

I think the worst possible outcome in this matter would be that Mr Ayers finds that he has insufficient power to properly prosecute his responsibility in this inquiry. As I have said, I have a personal regard for Tony Ayers. I think he is one of the best public servants that this country has produced. But we need to make sure that he has all the power and all the authority. I do not know what we have to do to appeal to the Prime Minister and to the minister that we want the fullest and the most vigorous open investigation of these matters.

For my part, not only is this issue of the 8Â½ months pregnancy so distressing but so also is the idea that we are administering, even under proper medical supervision, drugs to people whom we are deporting. I think it is awful. If you are a New South Wales policeman, you would not be allowed to do that. If you were transporting someone from Broken Hill to Sydney, you would not be allowed to do that. The Australian Federal Police would not be allowed to do that. Surely we need to have a vigorous system of catching people who are illegal immigrants here, or who overstay their visit, and properly returning them to their country; but not at the risk of newborn children and, particularly, not by invading the person. Departmental officials refused to deny the allegations that Senator Quirke had drawn up in the estimates commit tee. They said, `No, we cannot answer that.' They did not say, `We do not drug people,' or `We would not drug a pregnant woman.' An aeroplane would not accept a passenger, except under the most extenuating circumstances, who is 8Â½ months pregnantâand yet here we have government officials putting this woman on an aeroplane. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âToday I want to raise a couple of issues in this grievance debate specifically relevant to my electorate. Firstly, I want to draw to the attention of this House a most despicable campaign by the Wilderness Society in the south-east part of my electorate. It is a campaign where they have written to schoolchildren telling them an absolute litany of lies about the forest industry. Their letterâand I have here today a copy of one written to Eden High Schoolâmakes no less than a dozen statements that are totally untrue. By using these false statements, the Wilderness Society attempts to scare and to instil fear into those people subjected to this sleazy campaignâthat is, the schoolchildren. Many of these schoolchildren, I might add, have had to experience the job losses of their parents caused by the lopsided forest debate and the so-called restructuring of a sustainable industry. How dare the Wilderness Society tell these schoolchildren that:

speech.para: Daishowa . . . is poised for a massive expansion into the south coast forests of New South Wales.
How dare they say the expansion:
. . . would see hundreds of thousands of hectares of old growth forests, wilderness areas and endangered species' habitat, clearfelled and woodchipped.

The public has been duped far too long by these sorts of lies and half-truths bandied about by so-called conservation groups. To talk of a massive expansion of woodchipping is an absolute joke and an outright lie. It is also an insult to say this to a community that has worn the brunt of job losses in the timber industry.

Let us get the facts right. About five years ago, Harris Daishowa was processing about 640,000 tonnes of timber per annum. This was made up of pulp logsâthat is, logs that could not be viably used in a sawmillâthinnings, the heads and butts of trees that went to the sawmill, and sawmill waste. For that operation, about 450 people in total were employed, including the logging contractors, transport operators and those at the chip mill. The proposal for next year will be a total of 390,000 tonnes of timber to be processed, down from 640,000 tonnes. So where is the massive expansion? In fact, it is a massive contraction and, as a result, the total work force required now is reduced to about 280, down from 450. Many of those people who no longer have a job in the timber industry as a result of this reduction are the fathers of those children the Wilderness Society have targeted in their campaign.

Let me deal with the next statement about endangered species and clear-felling. How much longer are we to put up with such false statements by these organisations? I noticed, driving into Parliament House this morning, that the Wilderness Society was on AM making more similar untruths about another projectâthe Jabiluka project, with Alec Marr of the Wilderness Society constantly talking about Jabiluka being part of Kakadu National Park. It is not part of Kakadu National Park. I should know; I surveyed a good part of Kakadu National Park and the Jabiluka lease. It has always been quite separate. But they keep repeating these things until it becomes, in the minds of people, a truth; but it is not true at all.

Organisations such as the Wilderness Society continually run fear campaigns about endangered species and forestry. But, to date, they have not been able to identify one single species that has been lost to forestryânot a single one. You do not have to take my word for that. None other than one of the founders of Greenpeace will certify that. Patrick Moore founded Greenpeace and he has studied the forest industry in great detail. He understands and advocates sustainable forestry in Australia's native forests. He has confirmed that no group has been able to identify even one species lost due to forestry. But, in the face of such facts, the Wilderness Society continues to peddle their lies and their fear campaign, claiming that 60 species are in danger in the south-east region. The only species in danger are the species called timber workers and truck drivers and, consequently, many other people living in our rural communities.

This Wilderness Society campaign also continues the false claim of clear-felling. Such a forestry practice does not occur in the south-east forests. Forestry practices are in fact very strict and superbly controlled, with individual trees needing to be identified prior to logging. Seed trees, habitat trees and others are all retained as part of sustainable management. The Wilderness Society know all of this, but they continue their emotional but false attempts to paint a picture of a barren landscape.

The next false statement they make, clearly intended to create further fear and loathing of the timber industry, is the claim that the Deua wilderness is under threat. How can wilderness be under threat? Wilderness is wildernessâlogging does not take place in wilderness. In fact, under the RFA process, it is highly likely there will be additions to the Deua National Park and wilderness. But the Wilderness Society does not stop there. After insulting the intelligence of those who are the subject of their campaign with a long list of falsities, they then ask them for a donation. What a hide. Not content with having assisted in the destruction of so many jobs in the Eden area, their campaign now to residents and, in particular, more vulnerable schoolchildren is based at best on misinformation and at worst on downright liesâthen they ask them for money. This is yet another example of a disgraceful antiforestry campaign based on falsities rather than facts, based on stunts rather than statistics and based on politics rather than science. The people of Eden, fortunately, are too smart for the Wilderness Society and will reject their campaign.

I wish to touch on another matter today while speaking of Eden to update the House on events relating to the closure of the Heinz Greenseas cannery. I spoke about this a couple of weeks ago in the adjournment debate. Since then, a reference group set up in Eden has been identifying likely uses for the cannery site and has been pursuing existing businesses that could expand as well as new ventures.

Last Wednesday, I travelled to Eden with Senator Nick Minchin, Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, and met with the reference group, as well as a variety of people involved in local industry and potential business venturers. Minister Minchin was certainly impressed with the attitudes of the local business people, given the difficulties they are about to encounter. He was brought up to date with the proposed armaments complex and the multipurpose wharf and quickly learnt how critical those developments will be for the long-term survival of Eden. He heard of potential expansion of an existing fish processing company, of the possibilities of value adding to fish productsâfor example, smoked tunaâof the enormous possibilities in aquacultureâparticularly musselsâand of a variety of export possibilities, including timber products and spring water.

I must say that I have been very pleased with the response by all ministers to my plea for assistance. Senator Minchin and Invest Australia, for which he is responsible, have been particularly helpful and will continue to work with the local reference group on identifying new investors for the area. Minister Tuckey has gone out of his way to identify assistance for Eden, and he will work closely with his ministerial colleagues in putting together a package of assistance. I am also aware that the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Ian MacDonald, is taking an active interest. I look forward to his involvement as well. I have also had very positive responses from the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, John Anderson; the Minister for Sport and Tourism, Jackie Kellyâwho incidentally was able to announce a $100,000 grant to the Aboriginal Keeping Place Tourism Project at Eden; and the Minister for Defence, John Moore, whose department is currently working on the proposed armaments complex and the multipurpose wharf.

This has not been an easy time for the Eden community and, unfortunately, the toughest time is yet to come. While I acknowledge that the Heinz company is ensuring that all displaced workers will receive proper compensation and it is providing the services of consultants to help identify new projects for the region, I still lament that more notice was not given. Given the enthusiastic response that we are discovering exists within Eden's business community, I am confident that the jobs lost will ultimately be replaced. Unfortunately, it is next to impossible to do it in two short months. However, I will continue to do all I possibly can for the people and their families who will be directly affected. I will work with all ministers and their departments to expeditiously provide as much assistance as we can, directed towards those projects that the community itself sees as priorities for the region.(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âTonight I would like to discuss some of the issues surrounding the taking, treatment and prevention of drug use in our community. It is an issue that all members are undoubtedly concerned about and one that touches every corner of our country. Often, words such as `epidemic', `crisis' and `plague' are used to describe the current availability of drugs and their disastrous side effects. Whilst I believe that, as members of the federal parliament, we should refrain from usage of such emotive terms, unfortunately the drug problem fits all these descriptions and more.

speech.para: What can be done? This is a question that has dominated the media in recent months and has been the subject of angst amongst health and community workers in the drug and alcohol field, police and ambulance officers, parents, schools and the general community for many years. No-one pretends that there are any easy answers to the unrelenting dilemmas that the drug problem invokes. There are two very stark trains of thought that exist in the contemporary debate. The first is the approach supported by the Prime Minister, known in its founding country of America as `zero tolerance'. The other is a more innovative approach which looks at alternative ways of tackling the spread of drugs, like heroin trials, safe injecting rooms, decriminalisation and early intervention.

Most people accept that there are three main prongs to the attack waged on drugs: education, treatment for drug dependence and law enforcement. However, it is in the application of the three broad goals where divergent views emerge. I believe there is also a fourth pillar that is missing from this approach. I will come to it later. I would like to make a few comments on each of these and place them in the context of my electorate of Chisholm.

Education about the dangers of drug usage is always referred to as being one of the key weapons against the spread of drugs. The figures about drug usage amongst our children certainly imply that drugs are widely available in our schools and children are experimenting with drugs at a younger and younger age. Results based on data collected in 1996 from close to 30,000 young people showed that cannabis was the most used illicit substance by students between the ages of 12 and 17. Some 55 per cent of 17-year-olds admitted to having tried it.

As is stated in the ALP discussion paper on drugs, I believe education programs should include information on alcohol and tobacco as well as other illegal substances. Teachers and those working with our school community need to be trained in delivering education to students about the dangers of drugs, the benefits of a drug-free lifestyle and where to seek help if they become dependent. Programs that provide training of teachers about drug education, the production of resource matter and linkages with the broader community are to be encouraged. Some of these are already taking place.

There also needs to be education of parents and the community in general. One of the biggest problems recovering drug users and their families encounter is the prejudice and lack of awareness amongst their neighbours, friends and work mates. Many people still think of drug users as being wayward young people living on the fringe of society rather than next door. My electorate covers some leafy suburbs such as Surrey Hills and Mount Waverley where many people prefer to accept that drugs do not touch their familiesâand therefore they prefer to stay ignorantâbut this is not the case.

However, I also believe this attitude is changing. Recently, I circulated a drug awareness kit and was amazed at the strong reaction I received from parents who were concerned that they simply did not have information at their fingertips about the early warning signs. They were also concerned about how they could support their children and where to go for assistance. Many local primary schools and secondary schools have trialled drug education programs. Syndal South Primary School recently launched a program under the Turning the Tide initiative. These initiatives deserve to be promoted so we can equip children for the challenges that face them.

My only word of warning on school education programs is that we need to move away from the `just say no' message. I think it is fair to say that discouraging children from drugs in this manner only preaches to the converted. We need to reach out to those young people who are most likely to be tempted by drugs, by promoting a positive message that bolsters their self-esteem and encourages them to develop interests in a wide array of activitiesâwhich of course must be backed up by positive reinforcement by parents and carers.

The second major prong in dealing with the drug crisis I will term `support for addicts and their families.' This includes rehabilitation, needle exchange and detox and is known more broadly as harm minimisation. My office is located in one of the most notorious drug trafficking centres in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne. We are fortunate to have excellent drug units such as ACCESS, which is based at Box Hill Hospital. They are struggling to meet the demands of addicts wanting to come clean, and there is a waiting list which can mean a wait of up to two weeks. On the one hand, ACCESS sees this as a positive sign that people are aware of their service and are seeking help, but the waiting lists often mean that many addicts end up giving in and continuing down the spiralling road of addiction. There is obviously a need for greater funding to be allocated to detox programs and methadone programs that provide some temporary help for addicts.

One of the most encouraging signs I have seen under the umbrella of the Eastern Drug and Alcohol Service has been the development of in-home detoxification that suits many users. Waverley Emergency Adolescent Care has also campaigned to establish a youth-specific drug rehabilitation house in Clayton, which will run a 10-week rehabilitation service, family counselling and information services. Other bodies running initiatives which provide support for users and their families include the MonashLink Community Health Service, the Youth Adult Bureau in Nunawading, the Youth Substance Abuse Service and the new cooperative program run by Whitehorse Council, which is aimed at providing support to non-English speaking familiesâa much underresourced area.

Other harm minimisation strategies which have proved controversial have been notions of heroin trials and safe injecting rooms. These issues were canvassed at the recent New South Wales drug summit and have been roundly condemned by the Prime Minister. I find myself in the unusual situation of agreeing with the Victorian Premier that we must be prepared to try anything to curb the scourge of drugs. Whilst I accept there is a range of pros and cons to both of these strategies, I think they are both worthy of consideration, perhaps through a controlled trial. The support that the Wayside Chapel attracted in setting up its so-called T-room is evidence that community attitudes are starting to shift. As representatives of the people, we need to be open to new ideasâwhich brings me to the third plank of the traditional drug armour: law enforcement.

Certainly we must never forget that the despicable people who traffic in drugs also traffic in human misery. Whilst community opinion may have shifted in relation to harm minimisation, I believe there is still a resolve to bring to justice those responsible for profiting from drugs. The approach has generally been to try to limit the supply of drugs by cutting off supply at our borders or using police intelligence to perform drug seizures and crackdowns. However, no coun tryânot even America with its zero tolerance policyâhas been able to stem the flow of drugs.

Drug seizures have the effect of only momentarily denting the flow, and cracking down in a particular area only shifts the pushers to a new one. I believe a police presence is important because it may reduce illegal activity in the targeted area and improve the feeling of safety for law-abiding residents.
