This strategy and the resources that we have been prepared to contribute to it demonstrate that this government is more committed than any previous federal government to tackling Australia's drug problem head-on and doing everything we can to ensure that our children grow up happy, healthy and drug-free.

At the last election, this government promised to allocate new funding of $9.2 million over three years to support the two million Australians who suffer from asthma. The funding will go towards the development of education resources to improve the content and availability of information about asthma to those affected and improving adherence to management regimes; best practice guidelines on asthma management in different settingsâfor example, hospitals and post-acute careâand by different professionals, such as GPs and pharmacists; a systematic review of the factors that contribute to life-threatening asthma; a national system for the collection and collation of asthma statistics; and a national strategic plan for asthma to be developed involving all key stakeholders.

Another election commitment was that we would allocate $4.1 million over four years for support services for women who have been diagnosed with breast cancerâparticularly for those in regional and rural areas. This will provide much needed support to the women and families who are stricken with breast cancer, which is the most common cancer and causes the greatest number of cancer related deaths in Australian women.

One of the saddest things that any family would have to deal with would be the loss of a family member to suicide. Suicide rates in Australia are alarmingly highâparticularly amongst our young. At the last election, we unveiled the Fighting Suicide initiative, which will receive federal government funding of $39.2 million over the next four years. This initiative will include measures to increase education and training within communities, to build networks between primary care providers such as general practitioners and community organisations and to address risk and protective factors for suicide. Fighting Suicide will address itself to high risk groups such as youth, people with mental illness, prisoners, people with substance use problems and indigenous communities.

For about a decade now, the medical community has been very aware of the disease hepatitis C. A blood-borne virus, hepatitis C can cause complications leading to cirrhosis, liver failure and liver cancer. It is believed that 200,000 Australians have already been infected with hepatitis C, with 11,000 new infections occurring each year. The government is allocating approximately $12.4 million over the next four years to lower the current rate of transmission of hepatitis C in Australia by providing improved education and prevention and health maintenance strategies for those currently infected and those at risk of becoming infected.

All of the initiatives that I have talked about in the health portfolio deliver in full the promises that we made at the last election. This is a government that delivers on its promises. One of the most important health initiatives in this year's budget is the introduction of Lifetime Health Cover. Under Lifetime Health Cover, health funds will be required to set different premiums depending on the age at which a member first takes out hospital cover with a registered health fund. People who take out hospital cover by the time they are 30 and maintain their membership will pay lower premiums throughout their lifetime relative to people who delay joining.

Importantly, existing members of health funds who have hospital cover, no matter what their age, will be treated as if they had joined a fund by the age of 30, and a grace period will be provided until 30 June 2000 for people who are not health fund members to join up and be entitled to the same rate as the 30-year-old. This historic initiative will help to minimise future premium increases by boosting membership numbers and will help to balance the age distribution of fund members. It will help to ensure that the private health insurance industry remains an important plank in our health care system.

One of the great achievements of this government has been to greatly increase the resources allocated by the federal government to indigenous health. Building on initiatives announced in previous budgets, the government will boost funding by almost $100 million over the next four years. Indigenous Australians use the Medicare Benefits Scheme at only one-quarter of the rate of other Australians, yet their health needs are approximately three times higher. To help reverse this, the government will spend $78.8 million over four years to improve access to primary health care through the Primary Health Care Access Program. This will involve a range of primary health care services, including clinical care, illness prevention and early intervention activities. We will also be implementing coordinated care trials for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, building on the existing trials which have taken place in Wilcannia, Perth, Bunbury, Katherine West and the Tiwi Islands.

The Army-ATSIC Community Assistance Program helps improve essential servicesâsuch as water, sewerage, power systems, roads, airstrips and the construction and upgrade of community housingâfor indigenous Australians living in remote communities. We will be providing funding of $20.6 million over four years to extend this program to other remote Aboriginal communities. In the first four years of this government, we will have spent approximately 50 per cent more on indigenous health than the previous government spent in its final four years.

The other areas in which we have boosted support to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are education, employment and economic development. Some of our new initiatives in this area will include the Indigenous Employment Programâa new program addressing Aboriginal employment, involving total expenditure of $52 million in 1999-2000; growth in education expenditure of $16.3 million in 1999-2000, including on programs to improve literacy, numeracy and school retention rates; full implementation of changes to the Community Development Employment Projects Scheme, announced in 1998-99, which will allow participants increased benefits, including rental assistance and an additional $20 per fortnight Work for the Dole allowance; as well as the development of measures of relative disadvantage by the Commonwealth Grants Commission. This will help us to target resources more effectively to the areas of greatest need and fulfils another promise that we made in the 1998 election.

All of the initiatives that I have spoken about this evening are only made possible by the government's sound management of the Australian economy. The constituents in my electorate of Makin know full well that economic security is an important component of their social wellbeing. We all know from our own experience that when our finances are in order we also have less stress in the home environment and our family relationships are happier and stronger. It is no different when we look at the nation. Having the national accounts in order leads to lower inflation, lower interest rates and lower unemployment. This creates less stress on our social fabric. Balancing the books also gives us more room to move in important areas of social policy, such as those that I have discussed here this evening.

Families in my electorate of Makin have benefited from this government's better handling of the Australian economy. They are enjoying the lowest interest rates in 30 years, and this means that their mortgages are more affordable and their businesses can be more profitable. They are enjoying a low inflation environment for the first time in a generation or two. Although unemployment is still too high, it is continuing to fall from the disastrous levels that it reached under the previous government.

The short time that I have had could not possibly do justice to the many wonderful initiatives that we have been able to undertake through our careful stewardship of the Australian economy. Much work remains to be done. As a member of this government, I hope to achieve even more for families in my electorate of Makin, more for our indigenous Australians, more for older Australians and more for our children. I congratulate the Howard government on a responsible and compassionate budget, and I look forward to the further work that we will undertake on behalf of all Australian families.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) for this year's budget, and I would like to preface my remarks by saying that this budget is a nonsense, or a budget you have when you do not really have your heart in it, when you do not really feel like pushing the budget that you have presented.

speech.para: The real budget comes when the fate of the GST is known. This is now all tied up with what the government and the Democrats are up to, which seems to me to be a real attack on country people and small business, particularly small business in country regions which do not have the luxury of being able to choose how they develop their small businesses because they rely on a very small population base to keep them afloat. I think many of these businesses will just disappear. A goods and services tax on them will be the final straw. Who is going to actually police it all? We do not know those details yet. Who is going to help those small business people decide what to put the tax on and what not to?

I have a number of small bakeries in my electorate, many of which have a number of bread and roll specialties that would fall into the grey area of this tax, by some of the comments that have been made in the last two weeks. Will we have someone going around to inspect every bun in every bakery? What happens if the baker makes a mistake and charges it wrongly? Who picks up the tax then? Who finds him? Is he found? Are there tax avoidance police? Is he arrested and dragged off? The bakers have some major worries with this tax already.

The fact that this government copped this nonsensical stuff from the Democrats shows that Mr Howard must have been very desperate indeedâand desperate to keep his job. The more I read about this compromise, the more it makes no sense at all to be a part of the insane need to have a GST at all. Even with basic foods outâeven if one could define themâthe GST is unfair. Even the Commissioner for Taxation thinks the whole thing is unfair and that it will encourage a culture of tax evasion. Many of us on this side of the House have read reports that there is a lot of tax evasion in other parts of the world where these taxes do exist.

The people whom he has hurt most are those who can least afford itâthe pensioners, the workers on low incomes, the veterans and those in town and country regions without the usual access to ranges of goods and services. It is a regressive tax that will hit just about all the essentials of life that are not currently taxed. It is on all sorts of basic needs. Electricity, heating costs, housing, gas, phones, insurance, public transport and clothing will all be affected. It is not just the tax. There are other inequities, such as the problem of government ignoring the particular needs of small towns. A letter from one of my constituents in Job Network told me of some the problems being faced in small towns by that system. I have a FLEX 1 provider in the area with currently over 400 job seekers registered on their books. There have been no FLEX 2 or 3 contracts allocated in this region.

Employment National has been contracted to run the Outreach service, but they hire a very small office with no facilities at the local government service centre for one day every two months. This is no service at all. Rural clients are being ignoredâwhy can't they have the same service as their city based counterparts?

Another part is the tender process. The exposure draft for the next tender round introduces Employment Services areas. ESA is the smallest area within which a tender may bid to provide services. The draft says that strong preference will be given to tenderers who will provide services in the whole area of an ESA.

One country area that has previously tendered now covers a much larger area and includes a city in it. There is no way that the small provider can effectively cover anything but a small proportion of this ESA. Therefore the city based providers will be considered to be placed in a position to cover the ESA, and a country based provider, despite it being very efficient, will not be given considered during the allocation of tenders.

Tenderers are required to indicate their ability to service the majority of their employment service area. This virtually precludes all small regional based businesses from winning a contract. This will mean existing providers in rural towns will be forced out of the market if they do not have the capacity or the desire to expand. What will happen to their clients? They will not have a service in the future. Will they be compensated for additional expenses related to accessing providers in regional centres and regional towns? This would mean taxi fares backwards and for wards. In some areas in my electorate there is no public transport, so that would be the only opportunity. But I do not see that happening.

Then we have the problem that, although some of our city providers may indicate a willingness on paper to provide adequate services to rural communities, in practice this would not be the case. No-one has knowledge of their district more so than those people who live and work within their region and within their area, and those people are now being excluded under the next round of tenders. This attack on rural and regional areas goes on, and it is no good the Deputy Prime Minister continuing to explain how wonderful this government is being to the bush. We know that it is not true; the bush is hit every time you turn around.

Here is another one: the merit scholarship scheme that was put in place for low income students allowed bright students and bright youngsters to gain a place at university, despite their background, their economic situation or where they lived. Most of these were young people from country areas. There were 63 scholarships in Tasmania last year. After they have been through their courses, there will be no more scholarships based on merit. This is a major disgrace and a terrible thing for this government to have done. I have had several letters from parents whose children are presently undertaking their studies through those scholarships, and they are extremely disappointed with the government's position.

It is disgraceful that only people who can pay are welcomed at our universities. Some of those old jokes will be coming back, and it will be the norm again that only the privileged and the upper class will get a degree. It will be not what you know and how clever you are but who you know and how much you can pay that will get you a degree. Not only does this disadvantage students in rural and isolated areas but also it brings down the standard of the universities, which can now take anyone as long as they have the funds to pay for the course.

While talking about education, let me say that this budget has cut the heart out of our free education system. Country children do not have a great deal of choice about which type of school is closest to them. Mostly, they are government schools. I have no objection to having private schools receive additional funds. However, that should not be at the expense of the government's system. Schools that are already struggling through the cutbacks in the system have no chance of providing any equity in education. Who will suffer most? It will be kids in country areas who cannot get the transport to get to the cities and those whose parents do not want them to travel for up to two hours per day on a trip to a major city. They are forced to use the school closest to them. If that school is being cut back and its resources, including teachers, equipment, material and curriculum, are being reduced, the children in the rural and regional areas nearest it will suffer even more.

There is also this mean-spirited move to tighten the eligibility for legal aid for veterans. In the past under Labor, veterans were given special treatment when seeking to challenge administrative decisions affecting their entitlements. Veterans are now missing out because the merits test has become much harder. This government is trying to save money. Veterans are not getting what they deserve because they feel it is redundant to continue trying to prove they need the assistance.

Comparisons can be made with what this government has done in the general legal aid area. The only people who seem to be able to access legal aid are those who are prepared to plead guilty. If you plead guilty, you seem to be able to get legal aid and someone will come along to the court with you. That has been my experience in some recent cases I have dealt with in my electorate. It is not very good justice. However, that is the sort of pressure that is being put on the legal aid system. Recently, I saw painted on a wall in Hobart the message `There is no justice, there is just us'. It is a shame that our system has got to that.

Health is another area where people are hurting. I am not using the word `hurting' as a metaphor. I know someone who has had to wait two years to have a set of false teeth fixed because he is a pensioner and the government abolished the dental health scheme. He cannot afford a private dentist and private health insurance, so he has to suffer. Is this just? I do not believe so.

I have been working on a number of issues that affect regional development. I have put in a submission to the Standing Committee on Primary Industries and Regional Services, which is looking at barriers to regional development. The biggest problem throughout all the areas I have visited is unemployment. People in all the regions I have talked to have said that unemployment is growing because of services being taken out of the smaller towns. The government is not putting them back, and it is trying to make the private sector pick them up. Of course, the private sector will not pick them up if there is no reason for having them there. I have already mentioned Employment National. The family law courts have been taken back into the main cities. Country people now have little access to those courts and have to travel, in most circumstances, to attend them.

Telstra has shed jobs at a great rate. In Tasmania, people are waiting up to a week to get someone to look at their telecommunications problems, let alone fix them. That goes for people in small business. Recently, a restaurant in a reasonably isolated area had to wait a week to get its phones fixed. It meant that it could not order some of its supplies and that people who book by phone to use the restaurant could not do so. Not having that service cost that restaurant a considerable amount of money. That occurred because many of the technicians have been taken away from the jobs they used to do.

We have also lost an important percentage of research and development funding to some of the bigger companies and some of the bright, small companies of this country. This has caused problems even on the west coast. Some of the mines struggle to implement new technology when the price is dropping in the copper market. One of the most foolish things this government has been doing is reducing R&D. I would have thought that as a country we should have been endeavouring to encourage R&D through the taxation system and in every other way. They are the jobs that will come in the future and they are the jobs for our children. Cutting back on R&D and not encouraging it, as has been the case for education, is really a very poor policy direction for this government.

The poor old wineries are also copping it. There seems to be no sympathy for small wine growers, who are in the process of helping to build a viable and exciting tourist industry in Tasmania. They are being cut off at the knees because there was only apathy by this government towards a volumetric tax system, which is a fairer and more sensible way to treat the home grown product of small growers.

So it is cut, cut and cut again with this budget, and only the top end of town is to get any real tax breaks. I fervently hope that the Democrats will come to their senses and throw away this silly package of nonsensical stuff that has been hotchpotched together to make this terrible agreement which has enabled the government to say, `We've now got a deal, so we've now got a new tax system.' I hope that the Democrats will come to their senses and throw it out. I am sure that all those on low and fixed incomes would be very grateful if they did. Small businesses, the new tax collectors, I think would be pretty pleased as well, because they will not benefit very much from this tax. Apart from having people hanging around, looking over their shoulders, small businesses will have to work harder, doing more work and collecting more tax. Also, I understand that the compliance costs are about 30 to one, big business versus small business. So there is not much in it for them.

Who in their right mind would believe that this is good for business? Not only does the budget make no sense, but mix it up with the GST and we have a recipe for some real economic nonsense. We must fight this terrible tax. We must therefore fight this budget because it is very, very unfair.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1999-2000 . In the last week two events of significance for Australia have occurred. Last week Australia broke another economic record: gross domestic product grew by 1.1 per cent in the March sector for a strong 4.8 per cent growth for the year to March 1999; the economy expanded by one per cent for six successive quarters; inflationary pressures are low; and labour productivity accelerated to 3.5 per cent. All of this augurs well for a reduction in long-term unemployment. Business investment in plant and equipment has climbed 21.6 per cent, and consumption 1.7 per cent. To quote Alan Wood in the Australian on 3 June:

speech.para: This is an extraordinary economic storyâan economy running along at nearly five per cent, a current account deficit of around six per cent of GDP, low inflation, low interest rates and a calm foreign exchange market.
He went on to say:
So we can enjoy the good news for a while yet, including the prospect of further falls in unemployment.

The other event that augurs well for the coming years of the coalition government is the agreement between the government and the Australian Democratsâthe agreement between Mr Howard and Senator Meg Lees: a new tax for a new century. Not only is it a new tax for a new century and a new beginning for the taxation system, it is also refreshing: a redefinition of the political process.

In my electorate constantly people ask me, `Why do politicians argue; why don't they get on with the job?' It certainly has been very satisfying for people in my electorate to see two leaders with different policy platforms setting aside personal imperatives for the good of the nation. It has taken great strength of character on the part of both the Prime Minister and Senator Lees to work constructively and cooperatively to a successful outcome.

The historic agreement between the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Meg Lees, has redefined the Australian political landscape and, in doing so, has underlined the complete irrelevancy of the Labor Party. The ALP, reduced to a desperate display of mindless stunts and empty posturing, has dealt itself out of the process of defining a historic new taxation system for the next century. The Labor Party's rigidly inflexible determination to cling to the existing ramshackle, inefficient and arbitrary taxation system derives from little more than an opportunistic attempt to pander to those who are fearful of change.

By comparison, Senator Lees has shown a cool and admirable determination to make her party and its policies relevant and considered. Frankly, there is a wide and unbridgeable gap between many of the fundamental policies of the National Party and the Australian Democratsâand no doubt that will always be the case. However, I admire Senator Lees for her willingness to negotiate with the Prime Minister. All too often members and senators from all political parties are faced with the understandable public criticism that we are more obsessed with scoring cheap political debating points than actually working together to achieve better outcomes for all Australians. Now that criticism can only be levelled at the Labor Partyâ
Mr Fitzgibbon interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âYes, the shadow ministerâwhich remains dangerously single-minded in its sidelines carpingâhow well putâwhile at the same time cynically admitting that it would not change the new tax system if and when it might return to government. The Labor Party's political gymnastics are quite astounding. Its members pontificate against the redefined tax package; they remain silent about the shocking, arbitrary and inexcusable inequities in the current taxation system; and then they admit that, should they ever be re-elected, they would retain the system they now attack and deride. The opposition has reduced itself to a tawdry circus.

speech.para: On the government side the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Transport and Regional Services are all to be congratulated for their willingness and their skills in the negotiation process. I do not doubt that it is a difficult and exhausting process, but it is one that is in the best interests of the Australian people and it is admirable that those involved have put aside their personal differences to put the people of Australia first. Mr Speaker, I seek leave to continue my remarks at another time.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

debate.para: That the following bills be referred to the Main Committee for consideration:
That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âUnder the Howard government's Common Youth Allowance, former students aged 15 to 17 years who have left school are required to return to school or training in order to continue receiving government financial assistance. If existing students are contemplating leaving school before reaching the age of 18, they will also need to contemplate no longer receiving any government financial support.

speech.para: Labor supports encouraging students to stay on to complete high school. In fact, the proportion of students staying on for the final year of high school was doubled under federal Labor governments from 36 per cent to 72 per cent. The year 12 retention rate has slipped back under the Howard government to 71.6 per cent and to less than 66 per cent for government schools. The point is that obliging students to stay on at school is not an effective policy response unless the schools are given the resources to educate and encourage those students. That is precisely what the Howard government has failed to do.

The Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs sought from the government $140 million to finance the Common Youth Allowance for 15- to 17-year-olds. Cabinet instead approved $42 million, a shortfall of almost $100 million. In my state of Queensland, the then Liberal education minister, Mr Bob Quinn, issued a media release in January 1998 condemning the Howard government for its failure to provide the funds needed to implement the Common Youth Allowance for 15- to 17-year-olds and described the program as a classic case of cost shifting from the Commonwealth to the state of Queensland.

I took up the case on behalf of government schools in Rankin, only to be labelled by the same education minister as scaremongering. I wrote to the Howard government seeking assurances that the necessary funds for schools in Rankin would be available. I received such an assurance in response to my letter from the then schools minister, Senator Chris Ellison. Yet the government advised schools in the Logan-Beenleigh district that they would receive an average of only $20,000 each over two years, or $10,000 a year, and that after two years the program would need to be self-funding. I have no idea how schools were to make bringing back former students self-funding, nor do I think the government had any idea.

The next episode in this sorry saga occurred at the end of the last school year when schools in the Logan-Beenleigh district were instructed to have their programs developed and funding applications submitted within three days. They complied, but no Commonwealth funding was forthcoming. When I raised this issue in parliament on 22 March this year, revealing that Queensland had received no funding whatsoever from the Commonwealth, my remarks were greeted with interjections from government members protesting that this was not true. Not only was it true then; it took until 27 May for those schools to receive any funding from the Commonwealthâthat is, most of the way through the first semester.

At first, local Centrelink staff were effectively granting former students dispensations because they could not process the large numbers of young people who were facing the prospect of losing their entitlements. Now more and more former students are being required to return to school as Centrelink gets around to them. Existing students will suffer from class disruptions from former students who have been forced to return to school midyear against their will. Special programs could have been developed, but the funding is a pittance. The Common Youth Allowance is an ill-conceived policy and a poorly implemented Commonwealth government program.

The minister should abandon his obsession with crushing student unions on university campuses and turn his attention to sorting out the mess he has created with the Common Youth Allowance. This is not reciprocal obligation because it is not being funded by the Commonwealth government. We have an example here of the punishers and straighteners applying a punitive policy that is ill thought out and very poorly implemented. It shows a lack of concern for existing students. It shows a lack of concern for the returning students by not providing sufficient funding for these programs to be developed for the returning students. I call on the minister now to resolve the mess that has been created in Rankin, in other parts of Queensland and, dare I say, in the rest of Australia and to get this problem fixed so that the students who are returning have a decent education and the ones who are at school already are able to get on with their studies.

talk.start.para: âI rise to draw attention to one of the perhaps less noticed but one of the many excellent initiatives in this recent budget. It is harder to notice some of the smaller ones because of the many excellent initiatives such as the increased spending on health, the increased spending on education and the general efforts to restore some degree of fiscal balance and to further progress the great efforts we have made in this regard.

speech.para: I want to draw attention to the Green Corps program as this is one that has already been of great assistance to my electorate and provides a lot more potential. In this budget, the government has increased funding for the Green Corps over the next four years by adding another $90 million. This provides 6,800 places over the next four years, which is an increase on the 3,500 Green Corps places allocated in the 1996 budget. The Green Corps program is an excellent program. It provides valuable work experience and training for young people and it provides genuine, quality and tangible environmental outcomes.

Referring to those two aspects of the program, in terms of work experience, the young people who were involved in Green Corps for six months received quality hands-on training not just in environmental work but in a number of areas that will transfer to other occupations. During the six months they received 134 hours of accredited training. The core modules included occupational health and safety, first aid and aspects of environmental work. These modules are taken from Certificate II in Australian Land Conservation and Restoration curriculum. They also received specific environmental training related to the particular projects that they undertook and had a number of options there, depending on what sort of work they were involved in.

At the end of round five of Green Corps, 20 per cent of all participants who completed their placements were studying in education or training courses three months later. Of these, 21 per cent were at university and 52 per cent were at TAFE. A further 44 per cent of participants who completed their six-month placements were in unsubsidised employment three months later. Of those in employment, 51 per cent were full time and 38 per cent were part time. This has been an excellent program in terms of training and in terms of providing a valuable stepping stone for young people into other worthwhile training and other worthwhile careers.

The second valuable aspect of the Green Corps program is the quality environmental results that are achievedâvery measurable, very high quality tangible outcomes. The stocktake at the end of round five of Green Corps showed that already these young people have achieved this: they have conducted 1,101 environmental surveys; they have propagated 287,107 seedlings; they have constructed 416 kilometres of fencing; they have performed 17,693 hectares of weeding; and they have completed 302 kilometres of walking track maintenance. These are quality outcomes for the environment that are very evident and very clearly defined. Many of these improvements have in fact occurred in my electorate.

Two groups in my electorate have been conducting Green Corps programs. The first group is called Interlife, a subgroup of Mission Employment, working in the Blue Mountains restoring a disused quarry site that was a scar on the landscape that had been subject to heavy erosion and as a result caused siltation of the local Blue Mountains streams.

talk.start.para: âNear Medlow Bath.

âNear Medlow Bath; Wentworth Falls in fact. These young people have been involved in revegetation, creation of permaculture gardens and working on sustainable technologyâsolar passive buildings and self-contained waste management systems. This has been a great boon to that local part of the environment. The second group has been operating under the auspices of the Hawkesbury-Nepean Catchment Management Trust. They are in their second program now. They have been involved in revegetation of eroded river banks. They have been involved in environmental audit. They have been involved in removal of exotic weeds and construction of boardwalks in parts of the Blue Mountains National Park.

speech.para: Both of these programs have been very successful. Comments by the young people have included `inspiring', `best thing I've ever done', `changed my direction in life', and `I've learnt so much'. Part of the credit is due to the leaders involved in these programs and part due to the excellent program that this government has initiated and continues to support. I am pleased that this government in this budget is continuing and in fact increasing support for training for young people, support that will improve and prove to create positive tangible environmental outcomes.

talk.start.para: âIt is a shame the government does not extend the same principles across all of its programs.
âIt does.
âIt certainly does not extend it to Work for the Dole at all, and it is a disgrace that it does not. The sugges tion that it is a labour market program is pathetic.

speech.para: The budget is a very interesting document because it is very much a record breaking budget. It breaks records in a number of areas, particularly in the form of tax collection. It is worth while looking at the record of this government in terms of raising money from the public. In the last Labor budget of 1995-96, the PAYE revenue for individuals was $53 billion. In this budget, it will be $72 billionâa $19 billion or 35 per cent increase across four budgets. That is pretty good going. With zero inflation, almost negative inflation, there is a 35 per cent increase in PAYE revenue. That is a pretty good record. It pretty much typifies why the surplus is there. It is not because the government has been clever but because it has ripped money out of people's pockets like we have never seen before.

The next breakdown is tax paid by individuals. It is also pretty substantial. It has increased from $85 billion to $111 billion. That is only a 30 per cent increase but that includes PAYE. Members would understand why it is not quite as high: PAYE increases are going ahead at a much faster rate than non-PAYE individual increases. So 30 per cent is the actual average of individual taxpayersâPAYE and non-PAYE.

The next breakdown is company tax. Lo and behold, it has increased from $18 billion to $22 billionâa 20 per cent increase. So PAYE locked-in wage plugsâwe have no choice in payingâhave increased 35 per cent across four budgets; total individuals' PAYE has increased 30 per cent across four budgets; and total company tax has increased 20 per cent across four budgets. It is pretty easy to see what this government is about. It is very clear. It is all there in the figures. It is a record budget. We have never seen this kind of money raised in history in this form or with these kinds of increases.

Mr Speaker, you have been here as long as I have. You can go back and check the figures. If you go back to the Labor Party's previous four budgets, the increase was $12 billion, not $19 billion for individuals. Certainly the company tax differential was nowhere near as great. I think that is pretty interesting. It is also pretty interesting when we come to the GST, which will have a wonderful record. One of the things I have trouble explaining to people is why it is so efficient. Well, it is efficient because 1.4 million collectors will raise $30 billion. That sounds pretty efficient until you realise that at the moment 70,000 collectors raise $15 billion.

What the government is going to do in the name of efficiency is multiply the number of collectors by 20 to simply double the revenueâtwice as much money with 20 times as many people collecting it. Who will pay the cost of that? The fact is: we all will. That does not include the cost of administration; that is simply the cost of the actual number of people out there in the community being forced to act as tax agents. Sure, we forced 70,000 people to be tax agents. They do not get paid for that. It is a real burden. It makes their life a misery. But 70,000 collectors compared to 1.4 million for only twice the moneyâwhy would you bother? In terms of economic efficiency, it has to be one of the most inefficient moves ever made.

I went home on the weekend and, Mr Speaker, you will notice that I have had a hair cut, which meant I went to my barber. I go there on regular occasions and I get told the wisdoms of the world. Let me tell you from the barber shops of Australia, the wisdom is very clear and very focused. They do not want a hair of your GST, not a hair of it. Even though my hair is receding, my hair cut prices do not go down; in fact, they are about to go up, so my barber tells me.

I called into my second-hand clothing shop which buys clothes. She told me that she will be charging the GST, whereas the charities will not be, so her lack of competitiveness will get worse. She will probably be out of business in 1Â½ year's time. Across the road from her is Des's Humble Pie shop. I asked him if he understood the difference between food and non-food. That man has enough trouble working hard every day just to make a crust, but now he has to try to work out what the hell is going on. He is absolutely baffled. It is a dog of a tax. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise in the House this evening to pay tribute where it is dueâthat is, following the weekend's round of the Australian Rally Championship, to the organising skills of the Brisbane Sporting Car Club, of which I am a member and a big supporter. The Australian Rally Championship is something that goes on all over Australia and events, when they are staged, can require the contribution of hundreds of enthusiasts, volunteers and their friends and families.

speech.para: The Brisbane Sporting Car Club is an organisation that has been supporting motor sport in my state longer than any other club in Australia. Over the weekend, it staged a two-day event that was very spectacular. It actually began on the Friday with scrutineering of all the cars and all the activities that are involved with that, as well as an inspection of the course by the competitors. The event drew huge crowds, which is a very positive sign for the sport. On Saturday night, up to 3,000 people braved the rain to watch a very spectacular display of driving on a section of the old highway west of Noosa where it climbs up the mountainside.

I would like to pay tribute to the organisers from the Brisbane Sporting Car Club, particularly Errol Bailey, the Clerk of Course, who laid out the event and did much of the organising. He also was supported by sponsors. Falken Tyres were the major sponsor, and they were represented by John Thorn in Queensland. The town of Caloundra was the host town and the mayor, Des Dwyer, came out to lend his support to the whole event.

There were a whole range of competitors with a total of 72 starters from all over Australia, including the leading contenders in the Australian Rally Championship, Possum Bourne and Neal Bates. It was a big fight between those two competitors for first place in the event. On day 1, I think the result went to Bates and, on day 2, the result went to Bourne.

talk.start.para: âIn a Subaru.

âYes, Bourne was driving a Subaru. For once, Neal Bates actually won a heat. It was spectacular because of that. It seems that the petrolheads who are out thereâand there are a lot of themâare quite happy to come and stand in the rain and watch motor sport. It was a petrolfest, in fact. The contributors, apart from the Brisbane Sporting Car Club and Falken Tyres, included Mitsubishi, Chips and Bits, the Oasis Resort, Philcomm, Repco, Canon and the Queensland Department of Natural Resources. I must say that it is an honour to be able to acknowledge that degree of support for an event that has such a long history and which I think has got a very bright future. I will make no secret of the fact that I competed in the event.
âAs a celebrity?
âI would not say as a celebrity.
âHow did you go?

âOn day 1, we crashed out and on day 2 the clutch blew. Anyway, it was a very enjoyable event and I think the enjoyment I got from it was typical, because we had competitors ranging from newcomers right through to the highest level and I think every single one of them enjoyed it.

speech.para: Skills were needed to organise this event, as it included moving 72 competitors as well as the hundreds of people in the support crew and that kind of thing from one end of Imbil and the mountain ranges west of there right down to Caloundra to the special stage they presented there. It really did involve a lot of organisational capacity. The fact that the whole thing basically ran like clockwork over the two daysâwith the intervention of rain and all those thingsâis a credit to those organisers and the Brisbane Sporting Car Club. Once more, I would like to say to them, `Well done and congratulations on the successful staging of Rally of Queensland 1999.'

talk.start.para: âThe member for Blair has risen tonight to pay tribute to a sporting event in his electorate. It is my pleasant task also to pay tribute to two events that have happened in my electorate recently. The first is Tony Lockett's record breaking goal yesterday, and I am sure all members will join me in congratulating Tony Lockett on that monumental achievement. It was certainly very well received in my electorate.

speech.para: The second event was a more serious one and took place between 17 and 21 May, and that was the New South Wales government's drug summit. It was an extremely well organised and well attended drug summit. Senator Marise Payne and I were fortunate enough to be invited to be representatives from the federal parliament at that drug summit. It was a resounding success and I think it really paid tribute to all of the participants who went along, suspended judgment and worked very cooperatively to address the issue of preventing young people taking up the use of illicit substances. It also worked to bring us together and work out solutions for those people who are already, unfortunately, addicted to drugs and to deal compassionately with those people.

We heard from a number of expertsâfrom community and health workers, from police, from addicts and former addicts, from their families and from the New South Wales parliamentarians who are charged with finding some way forward for these people. I think the most important outcome of that week's drug summit was the realisation that there is no single solution for drug abuse in our community and that many different solutions work for different people. People were there who represented abstinence based programs. Brian Watters was there and he gave a very compelling argument for his programs.

But equally importantly there were people representing services that offer methadone and services that offer naltrexone rapid detoxification as well as naltrexone maintenance. I think those people made a very convincing argument that different solutions work for different people. The most important thing that we as policy makers can do is offer a whole suite of solutions to people and ensure that treatment is available to addicts when they are looking to give up the use of illicit drugs, and that those treatments are available on or near the time when people make the decision to give up, rather than weeks or even months after they have made that initial decision.

The summit made 172 recommendations, and the Carr government is currently considering those recommendations. But I would say that one of the most important ones was the recognition that there will need to be a significant increase in funding for drug treatment and education programs. There will also need to be a significant increase in family support because it is the families of drug addicts who most often are supporting them through that incredibly difficult period of using and of trying to give up.

One of the other most significant recommendations is that, in communities where there is a high level of street based drug use alreadyâand that does include some areas of my electorate, unfortunatelyâwith appropriate community consultation, and a consultation process that would be at least as involved as a normal development application process in the local government area, and where there is support for a safe injecting room that the state government not prevent that happening. That is a great step forward for people such as me who have been very interested in a scientific, medical and compassionate approach to people who are using intravenous drugs.

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of Senator Hill, it gave me great pleasure last Thursday night to launch on a national basis the Australian dry-cleaning industry regulation standard. This standard is the culmination of many years of hard work and consultation by the Drycleaning Institute of Australia. The standard will protect the environment, ensure the safety of dry-cleaning staff and contribute to the smooth running of dry-cleaning businesses right across our country.

speech.para: The Howard government was keen to be involved in the implementation of this standard as it addresses two issues of enduring interest to the government. Firstly, the Commonwealth is particularly interested to assist the small to medium business sector to help itself become more environmentally aware, and here is an industry keen to help itself to improve its environmental performance. Secondly, this government views air quality as one of Australia's most important environmental issues. We have not come to this view by accident. Surveys conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that air pollution continues to be the number one environmental issue of concern to the public.

In order to address the concerns I have mentioned, the government implemented in 1996-97 the comprehensive $16 million Air Pollution in Major Cities Program. This program aims to make inroads into the major sources of urban pollution by involving all sectors of the community. We certainly could not allow the pollution in Melbourne to be any worse than it is in Sydney. The Howard government has implemented Australia's first national standards for air quality and will implement national pollution forecasting and monitoring protocols. The Air Pollution in Major Cities Program is funded by the Natural Heritage Trust, and it sponsored the standard that we launched last week.

In 1996, the government commissioned the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences and Engineering to conduct an inquiry into urban air pollution. The government's initial response to the inquiry's recommendations was to fund a group of projects called `Clear the air'. In putting together this package, the government deliberately sought to include projects that brought together government, industry and the community to improve our air quality. The best type of cooperative initiative is this type of cooperative initiative. `Clear the air' includes a project to develop vapour recovery codes of practice for small to medium businesses, and I remarked on Thursday night that perhaps we might consider our own for this chamber.

I am pleased to say that, because of the initiative shown by the Drycleaning Institute of Australia, the dry-cleaning industry will be the first to establish and implement the code. This is not only a national first but an international first. Contrary to the views of their North American counterparts that said that it could not be done, it has been done in Aus tralia. I am sure our local industry will be more than happy to share their experience with their international colleagues in the year 2000 when the international dry-cleaning conference is held here in Canberra.

I would like to compliment the Drycleaning Institute of Australia on its thorough approach to the development of the standard. It addresses the interlinked issues of safety in the workplace and protection of our environment. The dry-cleaning industry regulation standard will make an important contribution to minimising the environmental impacts of perchlorethylene, otherwise known as perc, the major chemical used in the industry. While perc can be used safely, it is nevertheless a toxic substance and, if it is not stored, used and disposed of properly, it can be hazardous to both the air and the water quality around us.

Air toxics are pollutants typically present at very low concentrations, which are suspected to cause long-term health effects due to their properties of toxicity and persistence. The air toxics program will be seeking to work with industry to implement similar standards to the dry-cleaning industry regulation standard. The Natural Heritage Trust and the Living Cities program also address water quality. The Living Cities program will implement an urban stormwater program which will fund innovative and best practice approaches to stormwater management.

The dry-cleaning industry standard suggests measures to avoid spills of perc and other chemicals into stormwater drains. Acting on these measures will complement the government's initiative in these areas, and I look forward to assisting the dry-cleaning industry taking these further steps. The Drycleaning Institute of Australia and all its members should also be very proud of the initiative they have taken and the measures they are about to adopt to protect the work and natural environment.

It was a delightful evening. The institute's executive were very excited about their initiative. We had a lot of discussion about the 22 per cent wholesale sales tax they pay on all their chemicals. They are taking a very constructive approach to managing the envi ronmental impacts of the chemicals they use. They also recognise the very constructive approach taken by the Howard government to manage our tax system so that it looks after not only the environment and the people but also our economy in the longer term. I wish them all the very best with their continuing self-regulatory efforts to address the environmental concerns their industry presents.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Small Business

talk.start.para: âWhile the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business is enjoying himself in Geneva this week, the small business community in this nation is pondering the damage which can be seen in the wake of his decision to cut a deal with the Democrats with respect to the partial exemption of food from the GST. This, of course, will put a disproportionate burden on the small business community when compared to the larger retailers in this country. The estimates of the compliance costs on small business vary considerably, but you will see in a number of newspaper articles that it is up to $7,000 each year.
âOrder! It being 11.00 p.m. the debate is interrupted.

debate.para: (1) notes the importance of food labelling in providing consumers with accurate nutritional information;

(2) recognises that food labelling regulations must contain enough information so that consumers can be confident a product is good value for money, meets their health and nutritional standards and falls within their cultural and religious requirements;
(3) recognises that nutritional and dietary related illnesses are matters of public health;
(4) expresses concern at the Howard Government's deregulation of food labelling controls;
(5) condemns the Howard Government's failure to acknowledge and respond to the level of community anxiety over food labelling deregulation; and

(6) calls upon the Howard Government to reverse its decision on food labelling deregulation, work towards greater protection and information for consumers and maintain the health department's role in regulating nutritional and dietary matters.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 11 March 1999:

question.para: (1) Is it a fact that over 90 Gulf War veterans have applied for pensions related to service.

(2) Is it also a fact that core symptoms being experienced by the veterans include chronic fatigue, gastrointestinal problems, diarrhoea, chest pain, heart problems including irregular pulse and blood pressure, chronic headaches, eye pain, ear pain, stomach cramps, burning diarrhoea, urinary tract problems, burning semen, nausea, liver problems, kidney problems, bronchial problems, thyroid problems, sinus problems, anxiety, depression, mood swings, bleeding gums, chronic joint pain, muscle weakness, memory loss, reproductive problems, light sensitivity, dizziness, concentration loss, vision problems and bleeding bowels.
(3) Are statements of principles in force to cover Gulf War illness under the Veterans' Entitlements Act.
(4) Will he instruct his Department to endeavour to contact all Gulf War veterans and encourage them to seek medical advice should they experience the symptoms listed in part (2); if not, why not.
(5) Will he ensure that his Department covers the costs of Gulf War veterans seeking medical advice about the symptoms; if not, why not.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Veterans' Affairs; Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. My Department has received claims from 213 veterans of Gulf War in respect of about 490 individual diseases since the cessation of the conflict.

(2) These veterans have noted some of the symptoms you have mentioned. For example, chronic joint pain has been mentioned by many of these veterans in their claims to have conditions accepted as due to their service in the Gulf War, or their ongoing service as a serving member. However, these symptoms have been shown to be due to osteoarthrosis, the effects of trauma and well-known and understood diseases. Similarly, a number have developed Post Traumatic Stress Disorder, and they have anxiety and depression as part of this disease. My Department could find no record of a veteran who had complained of several of the symptoms you mentioned such as bleeding gums, light sensitivity and burning diarrhoea.

(3) There is no Statement of Principles for "Gulf War illness". Thus far, my Department has found that all of the diseases that have been claimed by these veterans have been covered by diagnoses that do not include "Gulf War illness". My Department advises me that there is, as yet, no generally accepted consensus as to what constitutes "Gulf War illness". However, my Department continues to actively monitor the medical literature, and to be involved in scientific discussions, on the nature of illnesses of Gulf War veterans.

(4) Those Gulf War veterans with an accepted war-caused disability are entitled to all necessary treatment for that disability and are issued with a white Repatriation Health Cardâfor specific disabilities. Veterans still serving can access existing Australian Defence Force health services and those discharged are always advised of their entitlements including future compensation and treatment.

(5) If Gulf War veterans are still members of the Australian Defence Force they are able to have medical examinations within the Defence health care system. If they have left the Defence Force, my Department will meet the costs of diagnosis for any veteran who wishes to claim that they have symptoms that they believe may be a result of their Gulf War service.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Aged Care, upon notice, on 23 March 1999:

question.para: (1) Will the Government provide additional funding under special needs for aged care assistance to centres with large numbers of special care residents who need to use unsubsidised interpreters in many aspects of their care; if so, when.
(2) Will the Government provide special funding to centres with large numbers of special care residents requiring staff to be trained in sign language.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

answer.para: (1) and (2) The Federal Government will spend over $3.5 billion in 1999/2000 on recurrent subsidies to residential care providers to care for individual Australians.

This funding is based on the individual needs of the resident, as assessed under the Resident Classification Scale. The Scale is used to classify each resident's care needs, which then determines the amount of Commonwealth subsidy paid to the residential facility.

The Scale already takes account of communication issues and difficulties, including difficulties caused by hearing impairment or through different language use. The Scale has been developed to reflect supervision, support and encouragement in providing care, as well as physical assistance.

The Government provides each residential facility with a pool of funding to meet all of the care and quality of life needs of residents. It is then the service provider's responsibility to meet these needs.
The independent Aged Care Accreditation Agency has been established to ensure that the care needs of residents are met.
Another initiative, Partners in Culturally Appropriate Care, links ethnic communities and service providers to assist services provide culturally appropriate care.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Aged Care, upon notice, on 23 March 1999:

question.para: Will the Government release the Productivity Commission's report on nursing home subsidies; if so, when.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Productivity Commission's report on nursing home subsidies was tabled in Parliament on 31 March 1999 and is now publicly available.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business: Australasian Research Strategies
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 530)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 24 March 1999:

question.para: Has (a) the Minister, (b) his or her predecessors or (c) the Department or an agency for which the Minister holds, or his or her predecessors held, portfolio responsibility, engaged Australasian Research Strategies, related companies or organisations or Mr Mark Textor to undertake research since 2 March 1996; if so, in each case, (i) what was the nature of the research, (ii) what was its purpose, (iii) what was its cost, (iv) was the outcome of the research supplied to a non-government organisation, individual or political party and (v) will the Minister release the outcome of the research.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a), (b) and (c) The Department, on behalf of a number of Labour Ministers' Council (LMC) governments, engaged Australasian Research Strategies on 22 May 1998 to undertake research on attitudes to workplace reform.
(i) The project consists of four phases involving a preliminary focus group phase; in-depth interviewing research; conduct of a survey and benchmarking of findings; and follow-up.

(ii) The purpose of the project is to obtain information on the drivers behind public attitudes to further workplace reform. The project is based on VISTA values research methodology, Australasian Research Strategies Pty being the sole Australian supplier of this methodology.

(iii) The contract price was $340 000 plus a maximum of $35 000 for travel. The first and second stage of the report has been completed with the running of a seminar detailing its findings on 3 May 1999. Decisions about proceeding to the remaining stages have not yet been made.
(iv) No.

(v) The Minister publicly released summary findings of the first and second stages of the research on 17 February 1999. A seminar outlining the research results from these stages was held on 3 May 1999, involving business, academic and media representatives.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Finance and Administration: Australasian Research Strategies

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 24 March 1999:

subdebateinfo.title: Diesel Fuel Pollution: Possible Health Effects on Sydney Residents
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 559)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 29 March 1999:

question.para: (1) Has an environmental impact statement been prepared on the possible health effect on residents of Western Sydney by an increase in the use of diesel fuel for transport following the relaxation of the diesel fuel levy.
(2) Has his attention been drawn to the high incidence of asthma among residents of the Sydney basin, particularly in the west.
(3) Have projections been made of the potential increase in sales of small trucks, vans and utilities fuelled by diesel rather than petrol.
(4) What measures are being taken to preserve the price competitiveness of low polluting alternative fuels.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (2) I am not aware of specific references to asthma in western Sydney, however, the draft Environmental Impact Study for the proposed Western Sydney Orbital (WSO) examined the potential changes in air quality arising from the operation of the WSO. The EIS concludes that emissions from an overall increase in vehicle kilometres travelled is largely offset by decreased emissions under freeway travel conditions. The study's predictions on air pollution from increased vehicle use assume worst-case conditions, for example, no allowance is made for replacing older vehicles with those fitted with threeâway catalytic convertors or controls on diesel vehicles which are being implemented through design rule ADR-70. Advances in diesel engine technology, and improvements in the refining of diesel fuel will yield significant reductions in vehicle emissions on a vehicle per kilometre travel basis, particularly benefiting residents in western Sydney who live in the vicinity of major arterials.

(3) The Bureau of Transport Economics (BTE), which is in my portfolio, has been commissioned by Environment Australia to undertake modelling work in relation to the proposed taxation changes. This work is intended to facilitate analysis of the impact of the proposed taxation changes on alternative fuel use.
(4) Alternative transport fuels are currently exempt from fuel excise. The Government is committed to retaining the excise free status of alternative fuels after the introduction of its tax package.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 30 March 1999:

question.para: Further to the answer to question No. 370 (Hansard , 23 March 1999, page 3509), was additional information requested by the Committee on Freedom of Association; if so, (a) has the Government provided additional information; if not, why not, and (b) what additional information was provided.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: As stated in response to Question No. 370, the ILO Governing Body's Committee on Freedom of Association adjourned its examination of the case and requested further information from the Government.
(a) Yes

(b) The Government has responded to the allegations that freedom of association principles were breached and rejected them. It would be inappropriate to disclose the detail of the Government's response before the Committee on Freedom of Association has examined the complaint.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 31 March 1999:

question.para: (1) Which States and Territories contributed to the printing and publishing costs of the report by Mr Des Moore titled "The case for further deregulation of the labour market" and what sum did each State and Territory contribute.
(2) How many copies were made available to participating States and Territories.
(3) What was the cost to the Commonwealth of publishing the report.
(4) Are copies available to the public; if so, at what cost.

(5) Did (a) he, (b) anyone from his office or (c) anyone from his Department approach the government of any State or Territory proposing that additional free copies, or copies at cost, be provided to Mr Moore for resale; if so, (i) who made the approach and (ii) why.
(6) If free copies were provided to Mr Moore, were any restrictions placed on their resale; if so, what were the restrictions.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) No State or Territory contributed to the printing and publishing costs of the report.
(2) Two hundred and fifty copies were made available to participating States and Territories on a complimentary basis, with any additional copies requested to be provided on a cost recovery basis.
(3) The cost to the Commonwealth of publishing the report was $12,348.65.
(4) Copies are available to the public free of charge. The report is also available on the internet homepage of the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business.

(5) The Department approached the participating State and Territory governments seeking their views on whether Mr Moore should be granted permission to sell copies of the report that the Department had agreed to provide to him, namely 250 copies on a complimentary basis and 750 copies at cost. This approach was made following Mr Moore's request to the Department that he be able to sell the copies of the report provided to him.

(6) With regard to the free copies provided to Mr Moore, the Department advised Mr Moore that the copies of the report provided to him could be resold, but with the restriction that he did not resell them at a profit and charged a price that simply covered his costs.

subdebateinfo.title: UNESCO Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 586)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 11 May 1999:

question.para: (1) Are there 95 parties to the UNESCO Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict (The Hague, 1954).
(2) Which countries have become parties since 1989.
(3) Was the Second Protocol to the Convention adopted by acclamation at the Diplomatic Conference at The Hague on 26 March 1999.
(4) Was the Australian representative a member of the drafting committee.
(5) Will the Second Protocol be signed at The Hague on 17 May 1999 in association with the 100th anniversary of the first Hague Peace Conference.
(6) Will Australia sign the instrument on 17 May 1999; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes, as at 15 April 1999.

(2) Twenty-two countries have become parties to the Convention since 1989. They are: Argentina, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Canada, Colombia, Costa Rica, Croatia, Czech Republic, Estonia, Finland, Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Lithuania, Peru, Slovakia, Slovenia, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and Zimbabwe.
(3) Yes.
(4) Yes.

(5) The Second Protocol will be opened for signature at The Hague on 17 May 1999, and will remain open for signature until 31 December 1999. The Government of the Netherlands intends to stage an opening-for-signature ceremony for the Protocol on 17 May 1999 as part of the 100th anniversary celebrations of the first Hague Peace Conference.

(6) No. Before the Protocol can be signed for Australia the department responsible for the Protocol must first submit it for the approval of relevant Ministers. If approval is obtained, the Minister for Foreign Affairs must then submit the text to the Executive Council for its approval for the Protocol to be signed for Australia. A pre-requisite for either of these steps is receipt by Australia of a certified true copy of the text of the instrument from the depositary (the Director General of UNESCO). The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has not yet received such a copy. My Department hosted an inter-departmental committee meeting on 6 May 1999 to report on the Protocol's negotiation and contents and discuss next steps, including which department should be the responsible department for the Protocol.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 11 May 1999:

question.para: (1) Is he able to provide the estimated cost of constructing the new Sydney airport.
(2) What is the breakdown of major expenses involved in building a new airport.
(3) Is he able to provide estimations of (a) what it would cost to relocate Perth Airport and (b) the time it would take to do so.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Three airport design options were developed for the current Environmental Impact Statement on the proposed second Sydney airport at Badgerys Creek. Based on these options, it was estimated that it would cost between $1.4 billion and $2.4 billion to build an airport capable of handling 10 million passengers per year, and about $600 million to build off-site infrastructure to service the airport. The cost of constructing an airport capable of handling 30 million passengers per year would be between $3 billion and $4.8 billion, with about a further $1 billion required for off-site infrastructure.
These costs do not include the existing airport site at Badgerys Creek, which was acquired by the Commonwealth at a cost of $125 million.

(2) The breakdown of costs involved in building a new airport would be greatly influenced by the type and volume of aviation traffic to be accommodated, as well as the nature of the proposed airport site. It is not realistic to provide a generic break down of costs that could be applied to any proposed airport.
(3) No. The possible relocation of Perth Airport is not an issue being considered by the Government.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, upon notice, on 12 May 1999:

question.para: (1) Under the Export Control (Hardwood Woodchips) Regulations, is there a national ceiling applicable to woodchip exports from regions not covered by regional forest agreements (RFAs); if so, what is the current ceiling.
(2) Do existing State management plans impose a maximum limit on woodchip production and/or exports in regions covered by RFAs; if so, what are the details.

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr Tuckey
talker.role: Forestry and Conservation; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Export Control (Hardwood Wood Chips) Regulations 1996 (the 1996 Regulations) make provision for the issuing of transitional, degraded forest, RFA and restricted shipment licences to export hardwood wood chips sourced from native forests. The 1996 Regulations provide that the maximum aggregate mass of wood chips that may be authorised to be exported under all transitional licences in force in any one year is 6.251 million green tonnes. There is no such aggregate ceiling imposed for degraded forest, RFA and restricted shipment licences.

The 1996 Regulations also provide a formula by which the annual aggregate ceiling for transitional licences is to be reduced by the mass of wood chips authorised to be exported under RFA licences issued to transitional licence holders. At the time, it was envisaged that RFA licences would be issued for a region once a Regional Forest Agreement (RFA) came into force for that region. This provision, therefore, ensured that as RFA licences were issued to persons who previously held transitional licences, the aggregate available under transitional licences for non-RFA regions should be similarly reduced.

However, the Export Control (Regional Forest Agreements) Regulations (the RFA Regulations) were made in 1997, which effectively removed the need to obtain a licence to export wood chips from a region once an RFA is in force for that region. Therefore, to ensure the purpose of the aggregate ceiling under the 1996 Regulations is not circumvented, Regulations 3, 4 and 5 of the RFA Regulations prohibit any increase to the maximum aggregate mass or re-allocation of transitional licence masses as a result of the making of the RFA Regulations.
(2) State management plans fall within the control of relevant State authorities. However, I am not aware of any State management plan that imposes a maximum limit on wood chip production.
Forests are managed for timber production. Wood chips represent the residues from silvicultural treatments, harvesting operations and timber processing resulting from that timber production.
